sources.original_official_filename: US - LEG - Respect for Marriage Act (2012) - OR-OFF (en).pdf

marriage_explan: American Samoa is the final U.S. territory yet to recognise same-sex marriage officially. However, the *Respect for Marriage Act* (2022), enacted into law by President Joe Biden in December 2022, addresses this by incorporating "any other territory or possession of the United States" under Section 7(b), encompassing American Samoa. This provision mandates the acknowledgement, though not the performance, of same-sex marriages legally conducted in other U.S. jurisdictions.

marriage_explan:
The Andorran General Council approved the Qualified Law on the person and the family (*Law No. 30*) (2022), which introduced marriage equality. However, it maintained a slight difference in the name between civil marriages ("casament"), which are open for same-sex couples, and Catholic marriage ("matrimoni"), which is not, although the legal effects are same. 
Shortly after the law was passed, the Social-democratic party filed a complaint with the Constitutional Court arguing that the use of different terms to label the union of same-sex and different-sex marriages is discriminatory. In its *Judgment in Case No. 2022-1-L* (2022), the Court declared this terminological difference unconstitutional, considering that it amounted to discrimination on the grounds of religious beliefs and sexual orientation. Following this ruling, in January 2023 the Andorran parliament unanimously approved a reform that uses the same wording for all types of unions.
civil_explan:
Implemented through *Law No. 4* (2005), the option for same-sex couples to register as "stable relationships" ("unions estables de parella") was established, offering only certain rights.
Subsequently, in November 2014, the General Council of Andorra introduced *Law No. 34* (2014), officially acknowledging same-sex civil unions as having "equivalence to marriage" concerning most family rights.
However, the Qualified Law on the Person and the Family (*Law No. 30*) (2022) replaced civil unions with civil marriage, although couples may still opt to register their partnerships ("unió estable de parella") without marrying, thereby obtaining recognition for certain rights.

sources.original_filename: UK - LEG - Marriage (Same Sex Couples) (Overseas Territories) Bill (2022) - OR (en).pdf

marriage_explan: In July 2022 the *Marriage (Same Sex Couples) (Overseas Territories) Bill* (2022) was introduced in the United Kingdom's House of Lords. If passed by both chambers of the Parliament, the bill will require the Governors of six British Overseas Territories (including Anguila), to legalise same-sex civil marriage within six months.

sources.original_filename: AR - LEG - Law 26.618 on Marriage Equality (2010) - (es).pdf
AR - LEG - Civil and Commercial Code (2014) - OR (es).pdf

marriage_explan:
Law on Marriage Equality (*Law 26,618*) (2010) is the federal law that amended the Civil Code to provide for same-sex marriage nationwide. Article 172 of the Civil Code reads as follows: “The full and free consent expressed personally by both parties before the competent authority is essential for the existence of marriage. Marriage will have the same requirements and effects, regardless of whether the parties are of the same or different sex".
In 2014, a new Civil and Commercial Code was promulgated. Under Article 402, "no rule may be interpreted or applied in the sense of limiting, restricting, excluding or suppressing the equality of rights and obligations of the members of a marriage, and effects that it produces, whether constituted by two persons of the same or different sex".
civil_explan:
Article 509 of the *Civil and Commercial Code* (2014), in force since 2015, made civil unions available nationwide for same-sex and different-sex couples.
Prior to this, civil unions were available in the Autonomous City of Buenos Aires (2002), the Province of Rio Negro (2003), and the cities of Villa Carlos Paz (2007) and Rio Cuarto (2009) in the Province of Córdoba.

marriage_explan:
Under Article 40 of the Statute for the Kingdom of the Netherlands (1954), “judgments rendered by the court in the Netherlands, Aruba, Curaçao or Sint Maarten […] can be enforced throughout the Kingdom, with due observance of the legal provisions of the country where enforcement takes place.” After years of political and social pushback, the Aruban legislature voted to amend the *Civil Code* (2012) to recognise same-sex couples from other parts of the Netherlands and afford them the legal rights of a married heterosexual couple. Same-sex couples, however, cannot marry in Aruba.
It was reported in June 2022 that the head of the Action 21 Party had drafted a bill legalising same-sex marriage to submit to Parliament for consideration. However, in May 2024 the Parliament of Aruba failed to pass the same-sex marriage bill due to a tied vote, with ten members in favor and ten against. 
In December 2022, the Joint Court of Justice of Aruba, Curaçao, Sint Maarten, Bonaire, Sint Eustatius, and Saba ruled in *Case No. AUA2020H00099* (2022) that same-sex partners must be allowed to marry in Aruba. The court emphasized that excluding same-sex marriages violates the constitutional prohibition of discrimination. However, in February 2023, it was reported that the governments of Aruba and Curaçao had appealed the decision before the Supreme Court of the Netherlands, thereby delaying the implementation of the ruling. In December 2023, the Attorney General contended that both countries' arguments were unfounded, as the antidiscrimination ban is consistent in Aruba and the Netherlands. In July 2024, the Dutch Supreme Court ruled in *Case No. 978* (2024) that the marriage laws of Aruba and Curaçao excluding same-sex marriage are not applicable. This ruling upheld the 2022 decision of the Joint Court of Justice and thus affirmed the right of same-sex couples to marry in Curaçao and Aruba.
civil_explan: Registered partnerships for same-sex couples became legal in 2016 under Article 80 of *Law AB-2016 No.51* (2016).

The law was approved after a national postal and voluntary survey, in which 62% of those who participated voted in favour of opening marriage to same-sex couples.
civil_explan:
Domestic partnerships for same-sex couples have been recognised since 1994 under the *Domestic Relationships Act* (1994). These unions were largely limited to an adjustment of property rates for domestic partners living under the same roof, with few of the rights and responsibilities of marriage.
The law was amended and expanded when civil unions were allowed under the passage of the *Civil Unions Act* (2012).

marriage_explan: The *Marriage Amendment (Definition and Religious Freedoms) Act* (2017) legalised same-sex marriage between two persons of marriageable age in all states and territories in the country. The law was approved after a national postal and voluntary survey, in which 62% of those who participated voted in favour of opening marriage to same-sex couples.
civil_explan:
Registration of domestic partnerships for cohabiting persons regardless of their sex or whether a sexual relationship exists between them was allowed as of 2007 with the adoption of the *Statutes Amendment (Domestic Partners) Act* (2006). While such partnerships were little more than contractual agreements between partners, the *Statutes Amendment (De facto Relationships) Act* (2011) expanded the rights of couples in areas of property ownership. 
In 2017, couples in registered in domestic partnerships again had several additional rights conferred in the areas of inheritance, pension, accessing a home-buyers' grant, and prison visitation rights under the *Statutes Amendment (Registered Relationships) Act* (2017).

sources.original_filename: UK - LEG - Marriage (Same Sex Couples) (Overseas Territories) Bill (2022) - OR (en).pdf
BM - LEG - Domestic Partnership Amendment Bill (2022) - OR(en).pdf

marriage_explan:
The Bermuda Supreme Court legalised same-sex marriage in May 2017 only to have the legislature legally define marriage as being “between a man and a woman” later that year. Instead, the legislature passed the Domestic Partnership Act (2018), which also defined marriage as solely between a "male and female". 
In June 2018 the Supreme Court struck down the prohibition on same-sex marriage once more.
Bermudan authorities appealed the judgement with the Privy Council of the United Kingdom, which ruled four-to-one in March 2022 against same-sex marriage in *Attorney General for Bermuda v. Ferguson and others* (2022). The judgement stated that "no restriction is placed on the worship, teaching, practice and observance of the respondents which manifests their belief in the validity of same-sex marriage. The protection of a ‘practice’ does not extend to a requirement that the state give legal recognition to a marriage celebrated in accordance with that practice." In response to this ruling, the *Domestic Partnership Amendment Bill* (2022) was submitted for Parliamentary consideration in June, which if passed would ensure the continued legal recognition of any same-sex marriages that were solemnised between May 2017 and March 2022. It has been reported by local media that 43 marriages took place under Bermudan jurisdiction during this time.
In July 2022 the *Marriage (Same Sex Couples) (Overseas Territories) Bill* (2022) was introduced in the United Kingdom's House of Lords. The Bill would, if passed by the House of Lords and House of Commons, require the Governors of six British Overseas Territories (including Bermuda), to legalise same-sex civil marriage within six months.
civil_explan: The Bermuda Supreme Court legalised same-sex marriage in May 2017, though this was repealed later that year after local government elections were held. In place of marriage, the Domestic Partnership Act (2018) was adopted, offering civil unions to same-sex couples but defining marriage under Article 53 as solely between a male and female. This law was repealed again the same year when the Supreme Court and Court of Appeal both ruled against the government’s ban on same-sex marriage. Bermudan authorities appealed the judgement with the Privy Council of the United Kingdom, which ruled four-to-one in March 2022 against same sex marriage in *Attorney General for Bermuda v. Ferguson and others* (2022), bringing the Domestic Partnership Act back into effect.

sources.original_official_filename: BO - JUD - Res Const 127 (2020) - OR-OFF (es).pdf

BO - JUD - CC - Decision No. 0577-2022-S2 - OR-OFF(es).pdf
BO - EXE - Res TSE-RSP-ADM No. 175 (2023) - OR-OFF (es).pdf

civil_explan:
In July 2020, the Second Constitutional Chamber of the Court of Justice of La Paz issued *Constitutional Resolution No. 127* (2020), quashing a resolution issued by the National Civil Registry (known locally as "SERECI") that denied registration to a same-sex couple in 2019. SERECI had alleged that the registration of same-sex couples was contrary to article 63 of the Bolivian Constitution (which limits marriages and "free unions" to those formed by a man and a woman) and to article 168 of the Family Code. On 10 December 2020, the SERECI complied with *Administrative Resolution No. 3* (2020) and ordered the registration of the free union. However, the validity of this registration, along with subsequent registrations, hinged upon a review mandated by the Plurinational Constitutional Court. 
In March 2023, this Court issued *Decision No. 577/2022-S2* (2023), in the case of David Aruquipa Pérez and Guido Montaño Durán. Through this decision, the registration of the couple's union was affirmed, thereby officially validating unions between individuals of the same sex, commonly referred to locally as “free unions". This decision also emphasised the need to align internal regulations governing the rights of LGBTI individuals with the protection standards established in international Human Rights agreements ratified by the Plurinational State of Bolivia. 
Subsequently, in July 2023, the Plenary Chamber of the Supreme Electoral Tribunal (TSE) issued *Resolution TSE-RSP-ADM No. 175* (2023), which brought modifications to the Free Unions Regulations (2016). This amendment extended the coverage of these regulations to include same-sex couples. As a result, same-sex couples can formalise their unions under the same terms and requirements as heterosexual couples.

After the dissolution of the Netherlands Antilles, Bonaire, Saba and Sint Eustatius became special municipalities of the Netherlands and, as such, Dutch law applies.
Article 1:80(a)-(e), Book 1 of the *Civil Code* confers comprehensive protections to both same-sex and different-sex civil partners.

marriage_explan:
*Resolution No. 175* (2013) issued by the National Council of Justice states that notaries cannot refuse to register same-sex marriages.
In March 2023, the Brazilian Chamber of Deputies reopened the discussion of *Bill No. 580* (2007), which sought to legalise same-sex marriage in Brazil. The bill, originally proposed in 2007 has been stalled for 16 years. 
In September 2023, *Bill 5167/2009* was introduced in the Chamber of Deputies to ban same-sex civil marriage in the country and, one month later, the Chamber's Social Assistance, Children, Adolescence and Family Committee voted in favour of it.
Moreover, in October 2023 Brazilian media reported that three bills were being discussed in a committee of the Chamber of Deputies aimed at banning the legal recognition of polyamorous relationships. 
In April 2024, local media indicated that the Senate plenary is set to debate a new draft proposal of the Civil Code to modify the definition of family. The proposed amendment specifies that "marriage occurs when two free and unimpeded individuals declare, in front of an officiant, their intent to form a marital bond, which is then solemnised by the officiant's declaration", a formulation that avoids referencing the gender or sexual orientation of the parties. In November 2024, the Human Rights, Minorities, and Racial Equality Committee of the Chamber of Deputies voted in favour of the the bill.
civil_explan:
In 2011, the Supreme Federal Court (STF) of Brazil recognised same-sex civil unions with erga omnes effects (i.e. applicable to the whole population) in two joint decisions: *Ação Direta de Inconstitucionalidade 4277* and *Arguição de Descumprimento de Preceito Fundamental 132*.
Early records from the ILGA World Legal Survey (1998) indicate that as early as October 1995, in response to several meetings with gay and lesbian leaders in Brazil, Marta Suplicy, a congresswoman of the Brazilian Workers Party, presented a bill to the Brazilian Congress proposing the legalization of civil unions between people of the same sex. Marta had originally launched the bill in June 1995 at the ILGA World Conference in Rio de Janeiro. Throughout 1996 the bill was analysed by a Special Parliamentary Committee which heard testimonies both in favour and against it. In December 1996 the Special Committee finally voted 11-5 in favour of the bill, modifying its name to "Civil Registered Partnership". The bill assured the right to heritage, succession, welfare benefits, joint income declaration, the right to nationality in case of a foreign partner and joint income in order to buy a house. The bill was due to be voted on by the full Brazilian Parliament in April 1997. However it came under strong attack from the Catholic Church: the head of the National Bishops Conference announced in late February that the bill was immoral and violated God’s law. The Catholic Church had earlier appeared to accept the bill, and Brazilian gay activists considered that the Pope John Paul II may have been behind the sudden hostility to the measure. The bill was stalled when activists and Deputies in favor of the law determined they did not have the votes necessary to win.

marriage_explan:
In June 2021 two women who got married in the United Kingdom filed a lawsuit against the British Virgin Islands government for refusing to issue them with a marriage certificate, and claiming that the ban on same-sex marriage violated the constitution of the territory. The High Court began hearing the case in July 2023. 
In July 2022 the *Marriage (Same Sex Couples) (Overseas Territories) Bill* (2022) was introduced in the United Kingdom's House of Lords. If passed by both chambers of the Parliament, the bill will require the Governors of six British Overseas Territories (including the British Virgin Islands), to legalise same-sex civil marriage within six months. 
In September 2022, Justice Adrian Jack refused an adjournment request filed by the Attorney General over a matter involving the aforementioned marriage between two women before the High Court. The Christian Council appealed the judge's decision and now it headed to the Court of Appeals.
In December 2022, the Cabinet decided to refer the matter of same-sex marriage to a referendum, as the first referendum in the history of the British Virgin Islands. A resolution on this matter must first be brought before the House of Assembly. If successful, a date for the referendum will have to be determined. In June 2023, the Cabinet submitted a *Draft Resolution* (2023) to the House of Assembly with its proposed referendum questions. The resolution addresses the existing provision in the Matrimonial Proceedings and Property Act (1995), which deems marriages void if the parties are not of opposite sex and the Referendum Act (2002), which empowers the Cabinet to refer matters for determination at a referendum when the Cabinet is of the view that "a special subject is of such national importance that it should be referred to the electorate for determination".

marriage_explan:
Same-sex marriage has been explicitly banned by Article 46 of the Constitution since 1994. 
In January 2018, the Sofia Administrative Court ruled against a lesbian couple who attempted to have their marriage, which was held in the United Kingdom, recognised. 
In July 2019, following the Coman-Hamilton case, the Supreme Court upheld a 2018 ruling by a lower court that allowed an Australian-French lesbian couple married in France to reside legally in Bulgaria.
However, in December of the same year, Bulgaria's Supreme Administrative Court refused to recognise a marriage between two Bulgarian women who had married in the UK. Both women challenged this ruling before the European Court of Human Rights, which in September 2023 condemned Bulgaria in Koilova and Babulkova v. Bulgaria (*Application No. 40209/20*) (2023) for failing "to satisfy its positive obligation to ensure that the applicants had available to them a specific legal framework providing for the recognition and protection of their union as a same-sex couple".

marriage_explan: The *Civil Marriage Act* (2005) is the federal law by which same-sex marriage was recognised nationwide. Starting with Ontario in 2003, most jurisdictions (provinces and territories) allowed for same-sex marriage before the federal law was enacted. The provinces of Alberta and Prince Edward Island, and the territories of Nunavut and the Northwest Territories were the only jurisdictions without such laws before 2005.
civil_explan:
Litigation by activists and organisations before Canadian courts allowed for progress in this regard in the late 1990s. As a result of a Canadian Supreme Court ruling in *M. v H.* (1999), there has been a constitutional requirement on Canadian governments to extend legal benefits and obligations to de facto same-sex couples on the same basis as opposite-sex couples. 
In 2000, the Canadian Parliament passed the *Modernization of Benefits and Obligations Act (Bill C-23)* (2000), which gave same-sex couples the same social and tax benefits as heterosexuals in common-law relationships. However, this law did not purport to overrule provincial laws and only applied to matters within federal jurisdiction. It also included restrictions that limited access to the Canada Pension Plan survivor benefit for same-sex survivors. These restrictions were struck down by the Supreme Court of Canada in 2007 in *Hislop v Canada* (2007).
Additionally, since 2001, specific legislation provides for civil unions and other forms of partnerships for same-sex couples in several subnational jurisdictions.

Same-sex marriage was approved in Quebec after the Quebec Court of Appeal upheld *Hendricks and Leboeuf v. Quebec* (2004), ordering the new dispensation to take effect immediately. Usually a 20-day waiting period is required for marriages in this jurisdiction, but this was waivered for the litigating couple so that they could finally marry. 
Later, the *Civil Marriage Act* (2005) would allow marriage between persons of the same sex to be recognised nationwide.
civil_explan:
In 1999, the Quebec National Assembly passed *Bill No. 32* (1999), which changed the definition of "spouse" and made changes in some 39 provincial laws and regulations that contained a definition of the concept of "de facto spouse" to ensure that same-sex common law spouses receive all the benefits and responsibilities of opposite-sex common law spouses.
In June 2002, the National Assembly of Québec passed the Act instituting civil unions and establishing new rules of filiation (*Bill No. 84*) (2002). This created the civil union, a new institution that allowed same-sex or opposite-sex couples to make a public commitment to live together and comply with the resulting rights and obligations.

sources.original_filename: UK - LEG - Marriage (Same Sex Couples) (Overseas Territories) Bill (2022) - OR (en).pdf

marriage_explan:
The *Marriage Law* (2009) of the Cayman Islands defines marriage explicitly as being between a man and a woman. This was briefly rewritten in October 2019 to be gender-neutral by the Chief Justice, per his constitutional authority, after a Grand Court ruling in favour of two women seeking to wed. In November 2019 the Court of Appeals struck down the amendment and upheld the territory's ban on same-sex marriage, but instructed the legislature to pass a law offering same-sex couples partnerships legally equivalent to marriage. After initially failing to pass by a vote, the Governor of the Cayman Islands used his executive authority to pass the *Civil Partnership Act* (2020).
The women who initially applied for marriage lodged a further appeal with the UK's Privy Council, which heard the case in February 2021, but dismissed the appeal in March 2022. All five justices on the bench ruled unanimously in *Chantelle Day and another v. The Governor of the Cayman Islands and another* (2022) that while nothing in Cayman Islands legislature precluded same-sex marriage from being adopted, "this is a matter for the choice of the Legislative Assembly rather than a right laid down in the Constitution".
In July 2022 the *Marriage (Same Sex Couples) (Overseas Territories) Bill* (2022) was introduced in the United Kingdom's House of Lords. If passed by the House of Lords and House of Commons, it would require the Governors of six British Overseas Territories (including the Cayman Islands), to legalise same-sex civil marriage within six months.
civil_explan:
In November 2019 the Court of Appeals upheld the territory's ban on same-sex marriage after the Chief Justice of the Grand Court had ruled in favour of two women seeking to marry. The Court of Appeals, however, instructed the legislature to pass a law offering same-sex couples partnerships legally equivalent to marriage. After initially failing to pass by a vote, the Governor of the Cayman Islands used his executive authority to pass the *Civil Partnership Act* (2020).
In December 2021 a judicial review was brought against the Governor by a conservative Christian preacher, arguing that he had acted unconstitutionally in using his executive authority to enact the law. In March 2022 the Grand Court ruled that it was within the Governor's authority to act, as the government's failure to offer an equivalent system to marriage for same-sex couples constituted a "breach of the European Convention on Human Rights". It was reported by local media in October 2023 that a representative of a conservative Christian advocacy group had requested leave to take the matter up with the UK's Privy Council, though the Court of Appeal refused this action.

civil_explan:
Articles 33 to 39 of the *Civil Code* (2021) set forth the "intended guardianship" through written agreements between adults, which allows a "guardian" to perform guardianship duties and safeguard the best interests of another person. Apart from the notarization of the guardianship, both parties also need to sign documents such as "property co-ownership agreement" and "inheritance or legacy support agreement". Thus, same-sex couples who sign up for the "intended guardianship" can, in some way, resolve issues of agency authority, property authority and inheritance division similar to those legally married.
Moreover, Articles 366 to 371 of the *Civil Code* (2021) acknowledge the "right of cohabitation" through binding contracts between parties, yet leaving the discretion for judges to interpret if such contracts between same-sex couples are valid to recognize their shared property rights. While there are different types of legal interpretation in practice, none of them favour same-sex couples. In fact, in April 2021, in *Yuan Gui Qin v. Li Feng Lan* (2021), the Intermediate People's Court of Shenyang Municipality rejected the possibility of considering same-sex couples' "marital" or "cohabiting couple" status. In so doing, the court upheld the first instance verdict.

marriage_explan:
In 2011, the Constitutional Court of Colombia issued *Decision C-577/11* (2011) recognising same-sex couples as “family entities” and ordered the Congress to legislate on the matter, though no formal law was adopted. 
After several years of legal uncertainty, in 2016, Colombia’s Constitutional Court issued *Decision SU-214/16* (2016), establishing that notaries could no longer refuse to register same-sex marriages.
civil_explan:
In *Decision C-577/11* (2011), the Constitutional Court held that while marriage could be defined as between a man and a woman under the Constitution, same-sex couples cannot be prohibited from legal recognition of their relationship. This led to the judicial recognition of civil partnerships, though no legislative reform has been introduced.
In 2022, the Supreme Court recognised in its *Judgment SL 2151-2022* (2022) the right of two men to a survivor's pension following the death of their partner, thereby giving legal effect to a polyamorous relationship insofar as the throuple lived together in a manner similar to that of a married couple. It further stated that the refusal to grant them such a pension amounted to de facto discrimination against the two surviving men.

In October 2019, a project that would have only legalised civil unions, as opposed to marriages for same-sex couples, was abandoned. As no law was adopted, same-sex marriage became legal as per the Court’s decision. marriage_explan: Croatia formally adopted a constitutional ban on same-sex marriage after a 2013 referendum on the matter was supported by 66.28% of those who voted. Only 37.88% of the population is reported to have participated, however. The *Constitution* now defines marriage as solely between a man and a woman under Article 61.

The *Same-Sex Life Partnership Act* (2014) provides comprehensive civil union protections regarding recognition and maintenance, but the law has been criticised for being weak in relation to parenting rights. 
In 2021 the Administrative High Court of the Republic of Croatia ruled in favour of two women married elsewhere in Europe who sought recognition as "life partners" in Croatia. Their claim had been initially rejected.
In December 2023, the Constitutional Court *rejected* (2023) three proposals submitted in 2014 to challenge the constitutionality of the 2014 Same-Sex Life Partnership Act (2014). The Constitutional Court pointed out that the right to respect for family life is guaranteed to all persons, regardless of sexual orientation and gender identity, and is under the direct protection of the Constitutional Court and the European Court of Human Rights.

marriage_explan:

marriage_explan:
Same-sex marriages cannot be solemnised in Curaçao. However, under Article 40 of the Statute of the Kingdom of the Netherlands (1954), Constituent Countries must abide by many of the laws passed in the Netherlands. Thus, Curaçao must register same-sex marriages legally in parts of the Netherlands and its constituent countries.
In 2018, a bill which would have legalised same-sex marriage was submitted to Parliament by a coalition of local CSOs but was withdrawn later without going to a vote.
The Court of First Instance of Curaçao ruled partially in favour of same-sex couples in *Human Rights Caribbean Foundation v. Het Land Curaçao* (2021) who sought to have the prohibition on same-sex marriage ruled unconstitutional and in violation of the European Convention of Human Rights (ECHR). The judgement declared its unconstitutionality and also noted that, instead of marriage equality, the adoption of some form of civil partnership might remedy the lack of recognition for same-sex couples. Both the government of Curaçao and the plaintiffs have appealed the judgement.
In December 2022, the Joint Court of Justice of Aruba, Curaçao, Sint Maarten, Bonaire, Sint Eustatius, and Saba ruled in *Case No. AUA2020H00099* (2022) that same-sex partners must be allowed to marry in Curaçao. The court emphasized that excluding same-sex marriages violates the constitutional prohibition of discrimination. However, in February 2023, it was reported that the governments of Aruba and Curaçao had appealed the decision before the Supreme Court of the Netherlands, thereby delaying the implementation of the ruling. In December 2023, the Attorney General contended that both countries' arguments were unfounded, as the antidiscrimination ban is consistent in Aruba and the Netherlands. In July 2024, the Dutch Supreme Court ruled in *Case No. 978* (2024) that the marriage laws of Aruba and Curaçao excluding same-sex marriage are not applicable. This ruling upheld the 2022 decision of the Joint Court of Justice and thus affirmed the right of same-sex couples to marry in Curaçao and Aruba. 
Meanwhile, in May 2023 an MP introduced a bill to ban same-sex marriage in the Constitution of Curaçao.
A year later, in May 2024, an MP announced his intention to introduce another bill to prohibit same-sex marriage. This proposal would amend the State Regulation by adding a clause stipulating that the only valid marriage is the one between a man and a woman, thereby excluding same-sex marriages.
civil_explan: The Court of First Instance of Curaçao ruled partially in favour of a same-sex couples in *Human Rights Caribbean Foundation v. Het Land Curaçao* (2021) who sought to have the prohibition on same-sex marriage ruled unconstitutional and in violation of the European Convention of Human Rights (ECHR). The judgement declared its unconstitutionality, and also noted that, instead of marriage equality, the adoption of some form of civil partnership might remedy the lack of recognition for same-sex couples. Both the government of Curaçao and the plaintiffs have appealed the judgement.

marriage_explan:
In 2018, *Bill No. 201* (2018) was introduced to amend the Civil Code to allow same-sex marriage. Over the next two years, the vote on the bill in the Chamber of Deputies was repeatedly postponed. In April 2021, several deputies proposed its withdrawal, but the proposal did not secure the necessary majority. Instead, the bill was referred to parliamentary committees for further examination. However, it was not approved before the October 2021 elections. On the same day Bill No. 201 was voted on, another bill was introduced to constitutionally define marriage as "the union between a man and a woman," gaining the required majority to proceed legislatively.
In June 2022, MPs from several parties introduced a Bill to reform the Civil Code (*Bill No. 241*) (2022) aimed at defining marriage in gender-neutral terms to legalise same-sex marriage. This bill prompted then-President Miloš Zeman to manifest his intention to veto it if it was approved. Moreover, a rival parliamentary coalition introduced a *Constitutional Amendment Bill* (2022) explicitly seeking to prohibit same-sex marriage. 
A year later, in June 2023, the Chamber of Deputies voted in favour of Bill No. 241 on its first reading, sending it to several parliamentary committees for discussion. Subsequently, on 7 February 2024, the text resulting from the committee debates was approved by the Chamber in a second reading. However, several amendments aimed at removing marriage equality from the text were introduced before the third and final reading. One of them proposed to not allow same-sex couples to enter marriages, but "partnerships" (locally referred to as "partnerství"), which would have the same rights and obligations unless legislation explicitly provides otherwise. On 20 February 2024, this amendment was approved by the Chamber in the third lecture of the bill. The approved text, which dropped same-sex marriage and focused on partnerships instead, was then sent to the Senate as *Bill No. 234* (2024), which approved it in April 2024. Although the amended bill would expand the rights registered partnerships enjoy in Czechia, it still fell short of granting them the same parental rights that married couples are entitled to. On 30 April 2024, the Czech president signed it into law.
civil_explan:
The *Registered Partnership Act* (2006) confers comprehensive civil union protections to same-sex partners but prevents same-sex couples from adopting children.
Article 3,020 of the *Civil Code* (2012) makes the provision that “the rights and responsibilities of spouses shall apply mutatis mutandis to registered partnership and the rights and obligations of partners” (referring to the first, third, and fourth parts of section on Marriage at Section 655).
In November 2022, a bill was submitted to make the registration of civil unions easier by removing the requirement to register such unions at only 14 selected registry offices. 
In June 2022, MPs from several parties introduced a Bill to reform the Civil Code (*Bill No. 241*) (2022), which aimed to define marriage in gender-neutral terms and legalise same-sex marriage. This bill prompted then-President Miloš Zeman to manifest his intention to veto it if it was approved.
A year later, in June 2023, the Chamber of Deputies voted in favour of Bill No. 241 on its first reading, sending it to several parliamentary committees for discussion. Subsequently, on 7 February 2024, the text resulting from the committee debates was approved by the Chamber in a second reading. However, several amendments aimed at removing marriage equality from the text were introduced before the third and final reading. One of them proposed to not allow same-sex couples to enter marriages, but "partnerships" (locally known as "partnerství"), which would have the same rights and obligations unless legislation explicitly provides otherwise. Thus, on 20 February 2024, this amendment was approved by the Chamber in the third lecture of the bill. The approved text, which dropped same-sex marriage and focused on partnerships instead, was then sent to the Senate as *Bill No. 234* (2024), which approved it in April 2024. Although the amended bill would expand the rights registered partnerships currently enjoy in Czechia, it would still fall short of granting them the same parental rights that married couples are entitled to. On 30 April 2024, the Czech president signed it into law.  
In July 2024, the opposition bloc in the Senate presented a bill amending the Civil Code (*Bill No. 267*) (2024) to limit some of the rights recently granted to same-sex partnerships. One of the amendments proposed would be to only include “registered partners” as opposed to “partners” into the category of “relatives”, which local legal experts have warned would increase uncertainty for same-sex partners and narrow their rights.

marriage_explan:
In October 2020 members of the Green Party started a petition calling for the *Family Law Act* (2009) to be amended to define marriage as the union of two adults, regardless of gender. The petition garnered more than 35,000 signatures (well past the 1,000 signature threshold which compels the Riigikogu (Parliament) to consider the matter) and was submitted in May 2021. It was sent to the Parliamentary Commission on Legal Affairs, which rejected the initiative in November 2021. In the Commission's *formal response* explaining its decision, it claimed that it could not support "unbalanced political initiatives which only serve to increase social conflict", that the existing legal provisions have not been reproached by any international court or organisation, and that other pending bills would grant same-sex couples with registered cohabitation agreements the same rights as married couples, if passed.
In June 2023, the Estonian parliament adopted the *Law to reform Family Law and other related laws* (2023), which amended the legal concept of marriage to define it in gender-neutral terms, thus legalising marriage equality. The president of Estonia enacted the law a few days after it was passed and it entered into force on the first day of 2024.
civil_explan:
The *Registered Partnership Act* (2014), which entered into force on 1 January 2016, is open to same-sex and different-sex couples and contains limited adoption rights for joint adoption by a second parent. However, "family status" under Estonian law requires a union between a man and a woman.
Effective implementation of the Registered Partnership Act reportedly remains sporadic, as many of the amendments to laws and provisions required to do so have not been ratified by the Riigikogu (Parliament) to date, meaning that some same-sex couples have had to have certain rights confirmed by the courts on a case by case basis. One example of this is the fact that the *Aliens Act* (2009) was not amended to recognise foreign same-sex partners of Estonian citizens seeking residence in the country, until the Supreme Court ruled in *Case No. 5-18-5* (2019) that this was unconstitutional.
In June 2023 the Estonian parliament enacted the *Law to reform Family Law and other related laws* (2023). Besides legalising same-sex marriage, this law extended certain rights and responsibilities to registered partnerships, including property rights, adoption, legal residency, and citizenship. These changes are scheduled to come into effect on January 1, 2024.

marriage_explan:
In 2017, Article 30 of the *Constitution of Georgia* (1995) was amended to define marriage as only encompassing unions between a man and a woman.
On 25 March 2024, the leader of the Georgian Dream parliamentary majority, Mamuka Mdinaradze, announced two draft constitutional laws: the *Constitutional Bill on Amendments to the Constitution of Georgia* (2024) and the *Constitutional Bill on Family Values ​​and Protection of Minors* (2024). Combined, they would amend Article 30 of the Constitution to enshrine the “protection of family values and minors”. These bills include a long list of measures that represent profound and severe regressions in legal protections related to sexual orientation and gender identity, such as only allowing the legal recognition of unions between "a biological male and a biological woman", among other proposals against sexual and gender diversity.
In May 2024, the Georgian Dream party introduced the Bill on Family Values and Protection of Minors (2024), a legislative package that amends 19 laws to implement the measures envisaged in the previous Constitutional Bills. According to a report by Radio Liberty Georgia, it would modify article 1106 of the Civil Code to define marriage as the "voluntary union of two people of different biological sex". The aim of this reform is to both to ban same-sex marriage and to exclude the recognition by Georgian authorities of marriages celebrated abroad by trans or non-heterosexual people. On 17 September 2024, the Bill was adopted in its third reading with 84 votes in favour and no votes against (as most opposition parties boycotted the voting).
Although the President opposed the bill and refused to sign it into law, the parliament passed it anyway in October 2024. ILGA World's research team is currently working on finding a copy of the adopted law.
civil_explan:
On 25 March 2024, the leader of the Georgian Dream parliamentary majority, Mamuka Mdinaradze, announced two draft constitutional laws: the *Constitutional Bill on Amendments to the Constitution of Georgia* (2024) and the *Constitutional Bill on Family Values ​​and Protection of Minors* (2024). Combined, they would amend Article 30 of the Constitution to enshrine the “protection of family values and minors”. These bills include a long list of measures that represent profound and severe regressions in legal protections related to sexual orientation and gender identity, such as banning the legal recognition of unions other than those formed between a "biological male and a biological female", among other proposals against sexual and gender diversity.
In May 2024, the Georgian Dream party introduced the Bill on Family Values and Protection of Minors (2024), a legislative package that amends 19 laws to implement the measures envisaged in the previous Constitutional Bills. According to a report by Radio Liberty Georgia, it would modify article 1106 of the Civil Code to define marriage as the "voluntary union of two people of different biological sex". The aim of this reform is to exclude the recognition by Georgian authorities of couples where one of the members is a trans person or is not heterosexual, including those formalised abroad. On 17 September 2024, the Bill was adopted in its third reading with 84 votes in favour and no votes against (as most opposition parties boycotted the voting).
Although the President opposed the bill and refused to sign it into law, the parliament passed it anyway in October 2024. ILGA World's research team is currently working on finding a copy of the adopted law.

marriage_explan:
In 2008, leveraging a legal loophole, the mayor of Tilos married two same-sex couples, triggering backlash from the Church of Greece. The government deemed the marriages invalid, leading to legal battles and appeals. Ultimately, the Supreme Court upheld the annulment in 2017. The court ruling allegedly reflected "Greek societal values" opposing same-sex marriage, citing the country's legal system as a reflection of its "moral and social traditions". While denying marriage rights to same-sex couples, it acknowledged the right to enter civil unions, affording them comparable legal rights to heterosexual couples in similar arrangements.
In June 2021, a draft bill was published for public comment. The bill would have legalised same-sex marriage and allowed same-sex couples to adopt, expanded co-parenting rights to same-sex spouses, and removed the requirement that married transgender persons get divorced.
In July 2023, the Prime Minister publicly supported the approval of marriage equality weeks after being reelected. After a period of public consultation in January 2024, the Government introduced its own marriage equality bill to the Greek Parliament on 1 February 2024. On 15 February 2024, the bill was passed by 175 votes to 77. The next day, it was signed by the President and enacted as the Law on Civil Marriage Equality (*Law No. 5,089*) (2024), taking immediate effect and legalising equal marriage in Greece. Although it was challenged before the Supreme Court, in June 2025 it confirmed the Law was constitutional.
On 18 November 2024, the far-right party Greek Solution submitted a  *bill* to repeal Law No. 5089, as it would contradict "Greek traditions and Orthodox Christian values", according to its proponents.
civil_explan: Article 1 of *Law No. 4356* (2015) confers gender-neutral partnership rights. In 2016, Greece’s *Government Gazette* announced the Presidential assent of a bill, which, in many ways, legally equated civil partnerships with marriages.

marriage_explan:
In April 2017, the Bill for the Protection of Life and the Family (*Initiative No. 5272*) (2017) was presented to the Congress of the Republic. In addition to increasing penalties for abortion offenses, it proposed amending the Civil Code to expressly prohibit same-sex marriage and define marriage as the union between a man and a woman "born as such", thereby excluding transgender individuals from its definition. Its approval on March 8, 2022 (on International Women's Day) elicited strong public opposition. As a result, on March 15, 2022, Congress shelved the law before it could be vetoed by the President, who had pledged to do so.
In November 2024, the “Parliamentary Front for Life and Family” introduced *Bill No. 6473 for the Integral Conservation of Society* (2024) in Congress. Articles 11 and 12 of the Bill propose amendments to the Civil Code to restrict marriage and civil unions to “a man and a woman, as born,” expressly prohibiting both same-sex marriage and the legal recognition of same-sex civil unions, while simultaneously reinforcing the absence of legal gender recognition in the country.
civil_explan: In November 2024, the “Parliamentary Front for Life and Family” introduced *Bill No. 6473 for the Integral Conservation of Society* (2024) in Congress. Articles 11 and 12 of the Bill propose amendments to the Civil Code to restrict marriage and civil unions to “a man and a woman, as born,” expressly prohibiting both same-sex marriage and the legal recognition of same-sex civil unions, while simultaneously reinforcing the absence of legal gender recognition in the country.

The *Inheritance (Guernsey) Law* (2011) does recognise same-sex civil partnerships solemnised in other jurisdictions for the purposes of property inheritance.

sources.original_filename: HK - JUD (HC) - Oct No. 295 (2021) - OR(zh).pdf

marriage_explan:
In 2019, a Hong Kong female resident and her partner filed an application for judicial review in *MK v. Government of the HK SAR* (2019) challenging the laws of Hong Kong as they do not allow for same-sex marriage nor do they provide alternatives, resulting in discrimination. Her application argued that this violates her right to privacy, her right to equality before the law, her right to marriage, and her right to freedom of conscience and religion (as enshrined by Articles 14, 15, and 22 of the Hong Kong Bill Rights and Articles 25, 32, and 37 of the Basic Law). The court rejected the argument that these laws were discriminatory, holding that there was no positive obligation for the government to recognise an alternative form of civil union for same-sex couples and that the word “marriage” in the Basic Law was always understood to reference heterosexual marriages only. The same was extended to the constitutional right to marriage, with the court refusing to extend the law’s interpretation to include a constitutional right to same-sex marriage. The court also referenced Article 19 of the HK-BOR, citing that it only protects the rights of heterosexual couples to marry.
In September 2020, in *Sham Tsz Kit v. Secretary for Justice* (2020), the High Court rejected a request for a judicial review to challenge the lack of recognition of overseas same-sex marriages or civil unions. The judge admitted that many current Hong Kong policies and laws on same-sex spouses may involve discrimination based on sexual orientation, but the request is too "aggressive" against the HK Basic Law. The claimant appealed in 2022, arguing that differential treatment from opposite sex couples violated the principal of equal rights for all, similar to the arguments made in MK v. Government of the HK SAR (2019). However, the judge at the Court of Appeals said that although Article 37 of the Basic Law protects the freedom of marriage in Hong Kong, the clause only provides access to marriage to heterosexual couples, not same-sex couples. In June 2023, Jimmy Sham Tsz-kit appealed to the Court of Final Appeal (CFA) seeking recognition for his overseas same-sex marriage registered in 2021. Subsequently, in September 2023, the CFA ruled in *Sham Tsz Kit v. Secretary for Justice* (2023) that the government bears a constitutional duty to register same-sex partnerships, while withholding full marriage rights. The Court identified a lack of legal recognition for such partnerships as a privacy violation under Article 14 of the Bill of Rights. The government is given two years to comply post the issuance of the final order. In response to the CFA's ruling favoring same-sex marriage, a Legislative Council member deemed it unconstitutional according to China's Constitutions and contrary to traditional Chinese family values. Consequently, they called for a re-examination of all previous Court of Final Appeal decisions on LGBTQ+ matters by the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China (PRC) to assess their alignment with the Constitution of China and the National Security Law of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (SAR).
In May 2022, the Equal Opportunities Commission stated in a meeting with the Legislative Council on Constitutional Affairs that they would engage in more research on sexual orientation and how it is discriminated against in law. It stated in its *Work Progress* (2022), that the internal study is ongoing. In response, the Legislative Council replied in their *Background Brief* (2022) where 'some members considered that the issue of discrimination against sexual minorities should not be addressed through legislation as they considered that this would result in “reverse discrimination” and would trigger more conflicts amongst people holding different views on the matter'. In a newspaper article, the legislation in question appeared to be focused on same-sex marriage.
On 16 July 2025 Hong Kong’s government introduced the *Registration of Same-sex Partnerships Bill (2025)* in response to the 2023 Sham Tsz Kit ruling, establishing a framework that grants overseas-registered same-sex partnerships limited rights such as hospital visitation, medical decision-making, and post-death arrangements; the bill completed its first reading and a Bills Committee was formed.
civil_explan:
Article 2(a) of *Cap. 189 - Domestic and Cohabitation Relationships Violence Ordinance* (2009) defines "cohabitation relationships" that also include same-sex couples.
In June 2019, the Court of Final Appeal held in *Leung Chun Kwong v Secretary for the Civil Service and Commissioner of Inland Revenue* (2019) that it was discriminatory for the government to deny same-sex partners employment and tax benefits. 
In September 2020, *Ng Hon Lam Edgar v. Secretary for Justice* (2020) HKCFI 2412, the Court of First Instance ruled that the exclusion of spouses in same-sex marriages from the legal entitlements and benefits that are accorded to hetero-married spouses under the Intestates’ Estates Ordinance (Cap 73) (IEO) and the Inheritance (Provision for Family and Dependants) Ordinance (Cap 481) (IPO) constitutes unlawful discrimination on the ground of sexual orientation. In June 2021, Ng Hon Lam Edgar v. Hong Kong Housing Authority (2021) HKCFI 1812, the Court of First Instance ruled that the spousal policy in the Home Ownership Scheme is discriminatory and unconstitutional, and overseas married same-sex couples will qualify as “spouses” and “family members” under the Home Ownership Scheme. The government appealed the decision and the appeal. In October 2023, *Ng Hon Lam Edgar and Li Yik Ho v. Secretary for Justice* (2023) HKCA 1224, the Court of Appeal dismissed the government's appeal to deny same-sex married couples' inheritance rights, justifying that same-sex married couples and opposite-sex married couples should own equal rights under IEO and IPO. In November 2023, the Hong Kong government intended to challenge this ruling at the Court of Final Appeal.
In September 2020, in *Sham Tsz Kit v. Secretary for Justice* (2020), the High Court declined a judicial review challenging the non-recognition of overseas same-sex unions, citing the challenge as overly "aggressive" against the HK Basic Law, despite acknowledging potential discriminatory practices. The claimant appealed in 2022, arguing that differential treatment from opposite sex couples violated the principal of equal rights for all. However, the Court of Appeals maintained that Article 37 of the Basic Law, while protecting marriage freedom, exclusively applies to heterosexual couples. In June 2023, Mr. Sham sought recognition for his 2021 overseas same-sex marriage at the Court of Final Appeal (CFA). Subsequently, in September 2023, the CFA ruled in *Sham Tsz Kit v. Secretary for Justice* (2023) that the government bears a constitutional duty to register same-sex partnerships, while withholding full marriage rights. The Court identified a lack of legal recognition for such partnerships as a right to privacy violation under Article 14 of the Bill of Rights. The government is given two years to comply post the issuance of the final order. 
In May 2021, *AA v. BB* (2021) HKCFI 1401, the Hong Kong High Court ruled that based on welfare principle, same-sex couples can have joint custody over one partner's children even they are not natural parents.
In October 2021, *Li Yik Ho v. The Secretary for Justice and The Director of Health* (2021), the government acknowledged the equal rights of same-sex spouse to arrange funeral for the other half, and the term "spouse" in the Coroner Ordinance does not distinguish between the same sex or the opposite sex.

civil_explan:
In 2007, the Hungarian Parliament passed the Registered Partnership Act (2007) providing same-sex couples with certain legal rights. However, on 15 December 2008, the law was struck down by the Constitutional Court in *Decision No. 154/2008. (XII. 17.) AB* (2008). The reasons for the unconstitutionality did not stem from the establishment of a legal institution for same sex couples, but it was primarily due to the fact that registered partnerships were also open to different-sex couples, and would have thus provided for the simultaneous existence of two similar institutions (registered partnerships and marriage) for different-sex couples. As a consequence of this decision, the Law on Registered Partnership and Related Legislation (*Law No. 29*) (2009) was approved in 2009. This law provides for registered partnerships for same-sex couples only, affording them rights similar to marriage except for taking the partner's name, joint and second parent adoption, assisted reproduction, and the presumption of paternity. Additionally, Section 6:514 of the *Civil Code* (2009) sets out the provisions pertaining to gender-neutral limited de facto partnership not based on State registration. The constitutionality of this law was upheld by the Constitutional Court in *Decision No. 32/2010 (III. 25.)* (2010).
In 2018 a Budapest District Court ruled that same-sex marriages performed abroad must be recognised as equivalent to registered partnerships.

marriage_explan: Iceland’s parliament passed *Bill No. 138* (2010) on changes to the Marriage Act, of which Article 3.1 establishes the right to marry regardless of gender. The law repealed the 1996 registered partnership law.
civil_explan:
In 1996 the Parliament in Iceland (the Althingi) passed the *Law on Registered Partnership* (1996). The law, which had been introduced by the Minister of Justice, also gave same-sex couples joint custody of the children of either partner. Both partners were allowed to become the children’s guardians. However, adoption was not legalised at that point.
In 2010, this law was repealed by the *Law amending the Marriage Act* (2010), which approved marriage equality.

sources.original_official_filename: IN - JUD - SC - Supriyo v. Union of India (2023) - OR-OFF(en).pdf

marriage_explan:
Following India's decriminalisation of consensual same-sex sexual acts, at least two petitions asked the Delhi High Court to rule on same-sex marriage recognition. *Abhijit Iyer Mitra v. Union of India* (2020) argues that the *Hindu Marriage Act* (1955) is gender-neutral in its wording. This act is one of three laws regulating marriage in India, the others being the Special Marriage Act (1954) and the Foreign Marriage Act (1969). The second pending High Court petition reportedly seeks recognition for same-sex marriages performed abroad regarding residency rights for the foreign spouse, on the basis that the *Citizenship Act* (1955) is gender-neutral in its wording. 
For its part, the Indian government has opposed these applications, reportedly by claiming that marriage is only applicable between a "biological" man and woman (i.e. cisgender heterosexual couples). However, the Madras High Court ruled in *Arun Kumar v. Inspector General of Registration* (2019) that the term "bride" in the Hindu Marriage Act is inclusive of transgender and intersex women, possibly nullifying this particular argument against marriage equality by the State.
It has been reported on numerous occasions that same-sex couples had started engaging in symbolic marriage ceremonies after decriminalisation, though these unions are not recognised by law.
In 2021 a bill titled Equal Protection of Rights for LGBTQIA+ Persons Bill (2021) was submitted to Parliament. The bill sought to legalise same-sex marriage, as well as provide the "right to recognition of LGBTQIA+ as families". Another bill was submitted the following year, in 2022, called *The Special Marriage (Amendment) Bill* (2022), which would amend some of India's marriage legislation to permit same-sex marriage to take place by replacing gendered terms such as "husband" and "wife" with "spouse". 
By 2022, many cases were pending in several High Courts seeking legal recognition of same-sex marriage, including the Supreme Court, the Delhi High Court, and the Kerala High Court. In January 2023, the Supreme Court absorbed all pending cases at other courts relating to this matter. In March, the central government appealed to the Supreme Court to defer the issue of same-sex marriage to parliament. The government argued that "same-sex marriage cannot be equated to traditional Indian family values, where the only legally recognised marriage is between a man and a woman, as husband and wife". Nevertheless, the matter was still heard at the Supreme Court. In October 2023, the Supreme Court in *Supriyo v. Union of India* (2023) determined that it lacked the power to permit same-sex marriages, citing that India's constitution does not consider marriage a fundamental right. In its ruling, the Supreme Court reminded the state of its obligation to recognise such unions while also stressing that the responsibility of creating legislation on this issue lies within the authority of the Indian Parliament.
On November 1, 2023, a petition was submitted to the Supreme Court seeking a review of the decision, arguing that the judgment contained clear errors, was self-contradictory, and manifestly unjust. Although the Court initially announced that it would reconsider its ruling and scheduled a hearing for November 28, it ultimately dismissed the review petitions in January 2025.
In November 2023, the Madras High Court issued an order urging the Tamil Nadu government to establish an administrative procedure to register "Deeds of Familial Association" to recognise civil unions between same-sex couples.

sources.original_official_filename: IE - LEG - Marriage Act (2015) - OR-OFF (en).pdf
IE - LEG - Civil Partnership Bill (2004) - OR-OFF (en).pdf
IE - LEG - Thirty-fourth Amendment of the Constitution (Marriage Equality) Act (2015) - OR-OFF (ie.en).pdf
IE - LEG - Civil Partnership and Certain Rights and Obligations of Cohabitants Act (2010) - OR-OFF (en).pdf

marriage_explan:
Although the Irish Constitution did not explicitly prohibit same-sex marriage, nor was it explicit that marriage was only "between a man and a woman", case law had interpreted that to be the specific content of marriage under the terms of the Irish constitutional text. In this line, it was determined that for the legalization of same-sex marriage, a constitutional amendment was necessary and, consequently, a call for a referendum, required under Article 46(2) of the Constitution for the validity of a constitutional reform.
The referendum was held on 22 May 2015, with 62% of voters supporting the legalisation of same-sex marriage. Ireland thus became the first country to legalize same-sex marriage by popular vote.
In August 2015, the *Thirty-fourth Amendment of the Constitution (Marriage Equality) Act 2015* (2015) was enacted, inserting Article 41(4) into the Constitution, establishing that "Marriage may be contracted in accordance with law by two persons without distinction as to their sex".
Subsequently, in order to regulate this constitutional right, in October 2015 the Marriage Act 2015 (*Law No. 35*) (2015) was enacted, entering into force on 16 November 2015. The next day the first same-sex marriage ceremony was held.
civil_explan:
Attempts to legalize same-sex unions materialized in various bills since the early 2000s. The *Civil Partnership Bill* (2004) introduced by Senator David Norris was one of them.
It was not until 2010 that the *Civil Partnership and Certain Rights and Obligations of Cohabitants Act* (2010) legalized same-sex civil unions, coming into force on January 1, 2011.
Following the enactment of the 2015 Marriage Act, these unions are no longer available. If a couple decides to apply for marriage, their civil union is automatically dissolved.

The law was initially slated to receive Royal Assent three days prior, with the Chief Minister of the island blaming the delay on the UK “Brexit” referendum to leave the European Union.

IL - JUD - Yossi Ben-Ari and others v Director of Population (2005) - TR(en).pdf

marriage_explan:
Same-sex marriage is not legal in Israel. However, same-sex marriages celebrated abroad can be registered before the Israeli Population Registry per the Israeli High Court ruling in *Yossi Ben-Ari and others v. Director of Population Administration, Ministry of Interior* (2006), which renders the civil (legal) status of reputed and/or same-sex couples equal to that of legally married couples. 
In June 2021, after several Israeli couples received civil marriage licences onine from the US state of Utah without having to physically travel abroad, the Population Registry announced that it would stop recognising unions issued online from Utah. However, several couples (including same-sex couples) married online filed a lawsuit. A court in Lod ruled in their favour, thus validating their marriages.

marriage_explan:
In 2022, several activists and MPs have filed an *application to celebrate a repeal referendum* before the Supreme Court of Cassation, a possibility included in the Italian Constitution to repeal an act or provision in particular. The goal is to abolish a provision in *Law No. 76* (2016), the law that opened civil unions for same-sex couples, that limits its effects to civil unions. This would potentially expand the scope of that law to marriages.
Between May 2022 and March 2023, multiple bills concerning marriage equality were introduced. In May 2022, several senators introduced *Bill DDL 2602* (2022), aiming to legalise equal marriage through a reform of the Civil Code. On 13 October 2022, the Movimento 5 Stelle party proposed the *Bill DDL 130* (2022) in the Senate, which, if passed, would grant recognition of marriage to same-sex couples. Similarly, on 25 October 2022, the party Italia Viva introduced *Bill DDL 215* (2022) in the Senate, with the intent to achieve legal recognition for same-sex marriage. Moreover, Alessandro Zan, a member of the Chamber of Deputies, introduced Chamber Bill No. 479 (2022) on 26 October 2022. If approved, this bill would reform both the Civil Code and the Civil Procedure Code to officially recognise marriage for same-sex couples. Continuing this trend, on 7 March 2023, Giulia Pastorella, another member of the Chamber of Deputies, introduced Chamber Bill No. 958 (2023). Successful passage of this bill would result in amendments to the Civil Code and the Civil Procedure Code, solidifying the recognition of marriage for same-sex couples.
civil_explan: Article 1 of *Law No. 76* (2016) regarding civil partnership and cohabitation establishes it is limited to same-sex couples. This legislation provides for equality in matters of tax, social security, and inheritance.

JP - JUD - Case No. (Wa) 447 (2023) - TR(en).pdf

marriage_explan:
In February 2019, 13 couples filed lawsuits against the Japanese government in four district courts (Sapporo, Tokyo, Nagoya, Osaka), claiming that not recognising same-sex marriages was illegal and that legislation prohibiting same-sex marriages would be unconstitutional.
In 2021, the Sapporo District Court declared that the lack of recognition of same-sex marriage was unconstitutional. In particular, presiding judge Tomoko Takebe argued that the provisions of the Civil Code and the Census Registration Law which deny legal effect to same-sex marriages run counter to Section 1 of Article 14 of the Constitution (right to equality). This ruling has been described as "groundbreaking" by Japanese activists and has encouraged more couples to file their own lawsuits. Although it was appealed, in March 2024 the Sapporo High Court reaffirmed that the lack of legal recognition of same-sex marriages by the current Civil Code and Family Registration Law is unconstitutional, violating Articles 14(1), 24(1) and 24(2) of the Constitution, yet refused to award any compensation. The plaintiffs appealed to the Supreme Court, seeking its first ruling on the unconstitutionality of the ban on same-sex marriages.
However, in June 2022, the Osaka District Court reached a different conclusion and held that Japan's ban on same-sex marriage was compatible with the Constitution, arguing that the disadvantages suffered by the applicants under the current law could be resolved using other provisions of Japanese civil law. For this reason, it held that the ban on same-sex marriage would not violate Article 14 of the Constitution. The plaintiffs appealed this decision.
In addition, in October 2022, a US citizen who had married a Japanese citizen in the US appealed to the Tokyo High Court the Tokyo District Court's decision to deny his application for a visa to stay in Japan and live with his husband.
Later, in November 2022, the Tokyo District Court became the third district court to rule on the absence of same-sex marriage in Japan in *Case No. (Wa) 3465* (2022). The court declared that the ban represents an "unconstitutional state". While accepting the plaintiffs' argument that the absence of a legal system allowing same-sex couples to marry contravened Article 24(2) of the Constitution, the court nevertheless maintained the ban.  
In this judicial context, on 3 March 2023 the Democratic Constitutional Party of Japan introduced a *Bill to Revise the Civil Code* (2023), which would legalise same-sex marriage by using gender-neutral language in the law and explicitly mentioning "parties... [of] the same sex" in the article on marriage. 
In May 2023, the Nagoya District Court declared in *Case No. 597* (2023) that the ban on same-sex marriage violated Articles 14 (equality) and 24 (family rights) of the Japanese Constitution. In March 2025, the Nagoya High Court upheld this decision, finding that the Civil Code and Family Registry Law provisions excluding same-sex couples “lack a reasonable basis and constitute unlawful discrimination,” undermine family well-being in medical and legal contexts, and risk privacy violations by forcing LGBTQ+ individuals to disclose their sexual orientation.
Then, on 8 June 2023, the Fukuoka District Court also ruled in *Case No. 447* (2023) that the existing laws which do not grant same-sex couples any marriage benefits and do not give them the means to form a family with the partner of their choice were unconstitutional. As in other rulings, the Fukuoka District Court also found these laws to be in violation of Article 24(2) of the Constitution of Japan. This was the fifth ruling on the constitutionality of Japan's lack of same-sex marriage laws. Subsequently, in December 2024, after the plaintiffs appealed, the Fukuoka High Court upheld the ruling on unconstitutionality and became the first court in Japan to also declare that the lack of same-sex marriage protections violated Article 13 of the Constitution, which guarantees the right to pursue happiness.
Moreover, in September 2023, the Sapporo District Court refused to award compensation to a same-sex couple for ineligibility for marriage benefits. According to press reports, the plaintiff couple decided not to appeal, so the ruling became final. 
In March 2024, the Tokyo District Court ruled again on the absence of same-sex marriage in Japan, the sixth time a Japanese court had decided on this issue. The District Court ruled that not recognising same-sex marriage violates Article 24(2) of the Constitution, which guarantees “equality of the sexes” in family and marriage law. However, they also ruled that it does not violate Article 14(1), which stipulates equality before the law, or Article 24(1) which guarantees freedom of marriage. The plaintiffs appeled against this decision to the Tokyo High Court, which began hearing the case in late September 2024. On 30 October 2024, the High Court upheld the unconstitutionality argument, adding that Japan’s curent non-recognition of same-sex marriage violates Articles 24(2) as well as Article 14(1) of the Constitution. The Tokyo High Court called the ongoing ban "a groundless legal discrimination based on sexual orientation," saying it violates the constitutional guarantee of right to equality, as well as individuals' dignity and equality between sexes.
civil_explan:
Japan has no nationwide law recognising same-sex civil unions or marriages. However, since 2019 several prefectures (Japan's first level of administrative divisions) and hundreds of other local administrations have recognised same-sex couples by issuing "partnership certificates". These certificates allow same-sex partners to access housing programmes together, give consent to each other's medical treatments or visit each other at the hospital.
Moreover, some prefectures have started signing agreements among themselves to mutually recognise legal partnership certificates issued by the prefectures that are part of the agreement. For instance, Saga has signed agreements with Fukuoka and Ibaraki, while Ibaraki has signed similar agreements with Gunma and Tochigi. In the absence of a nationwide mechanism, these agreements allow same-sex couples to be legally recognised as such beyond the borders of their prefecture.

In 2019 officials in Ibaraki Prefecture announced that they would begin issuing “partnership certificates” to same-sex couples. These certificates allow couples to rent public housing together and give consent to medical procedures on behalf of an incapacitated partner.
In May 2023, local media reported that the Ishikawa Prefecture had announced its plans to approve a partnership registration system to legally recognise same-sex partnerships.

In September 2023, the governor of Kagawa announced that a same-sex partnership registration system will be implemented in the prefecture starting on 1 October 2023. Previously, all 17 municipalities of Kagawa had already implemented same-sex partnership recognition systems at the local level.

Since April 2024, Oita Prefecture has implemented a partnership registration system to legally recognise same-sex relationships.
In March 2025, it was reported that Okinawa authorities had started implementing its own partnership registration system for same-sex couples.

This ordinance allows same-sex couples to register their partnership, making it the second Prefecture in Japan to do so. Local legislation has also been expanded to make widowed same-sex partners of deceased persons eligible for familial compensation grants.

civil_explan:
In October 2018, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government established the *Tokyo Olympic Charter Ordinance for Human Rights* (2018) to realize the principle of respect for human rights. This includes the elimination of unjust discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity.
In 2021, the Metropolitan Government of Tokyo announced that a legal partnership system will be adopted in November 2022. Furthermore, Kunitachi City, Tokyo, amended the *Ordinance for City Employees* (2021) to allow employees who have specific partners, including LGBT people, to take leave and welfare programs equivalent to legal marriage.
In June 2022, the Tokyo Olympic Charter Ordinance for Human Rights (2018) was revised to establish the new "Tokyo Partnership Oath System". Starting on 11 October 2022, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government began to accept applications for the "Tokyo Partnership Oath System" that officially recognises family relationships for sexual minority (LGBTQ) couples (see the government's official *Tokyo Partnership Oath System Guide* (2022) for further details, including the eligibility for couples with only one party living in Tokyo). Since 1 November 2022, the Tokyo partnership oath system is officially in force.
In October 2023, the Tottori prefecture implemented a legal partnership system to legally recognise same-sex couples.

civil_explan: In 2022, the Toyama prefecture announced its intention to adopt a partnership system for same-sex couples, which was implemented on 1 March 2023 with the *Toyama Prefecture Partnership Pledge System* (2023).
As of 1 February 2024, Wakayama Prefecture implemented a partnership registration system to legally recognise same-sex couples.
In December 2023, the Yamagata prefecture announced its intention to introduce a partnership system for same-sex couples in January 2024.

In January 2024, the governor of the Yamaguchi prefecture announced his government's plans to approve a partnership registration system for same-sex couples. According to Japanese media, the system will be implemented in September 2024.

According to local media, the Yamanashi prefecture has announced its intention to approve a partnership system for same-sex couples. This system was expected to be implemented in November 2023. However, ILGA World's research team has not been able to confirm if the system has been adopted yet.

marriage_explan:
In February 2023, the *Family Protection Bill* (2023) was introduced to amend Article 45(2) of the Constitution on the definition of "family" and amend Section 162 of the Penal Code (1930) to criminalise same-sex marriages.
In October 2023, the *National Policy on Family Promotion and Protection “Happy and Stable Families For a Strong Society”* (2023) was approved by the Ministry of Labour and Social Protection. Under this policy, "family" is defined as "a societal group that is related by blood (kinship), adoption, foster care or the ties of marriage (civil, customary or religious) of two persons of opposite sex". Furthermore, under Section 2.4, "efforts to guide and nurture families with skills to inculcate, internalise and practice good moral and family values" are included among the rationale for the policy. In the same line, "promoting gender responsive and age appropriate programs that help people understand sexuality framed in the context of marriage as the best option" is included as a priority for policy interventions by government in collaboration with relevant stakeholders.

sources.original_filename: XK - LEG - Draft Civil Code of the Republic of Kosovo (2023) - OR(en).pdf
XK - LEG - Draft Civil Code of the Republic of Kosovo (2023) - OR(en).pdf

marriage_explan:
In March 2022, a Bill for a new Civil Code was introduced in the Kosovo Parliament. Article 1138 would have banned same-sex marriage by defining marriage as "a legally registered union of two spouses of different sexes". Still, it would also have permitted other forms of civil union to be regulated through specific legislation in future. The bill was later rejected.
In 2023 a new *Draft Civil Code of the Republic of Kosovo* (2023) was adopted. Following the previous bill, it banned same-sex marriage under Article 1138, although it could still allow other kinds of unions.
civil_explan:
In March 2022, a Bill for a new Civil Code was introduced in the Kosovo Parliament. Article 1138 would have banned same-sex marriage by defining marriage as "a legally registered union of two spouses of different sexes". Still, it would also have permitted other forms of civil union to be regulated through specific legislation in future. The bill was later rejected.
In 2023 a new *Draft Civil Code of the Republic of Kosovo* (2023) was adopted. Following the previous bill, it banned same-sex marriage under Article 1138, although it could still allow other kinds of unions. In this spirit, local sources reported in April 2024 that the Prime Minister had announced the government’s plans to allow same-sex civil unions.
