sources.original_official_filename: LV - LEG - Bill 1380 Civil Union Law (2022) - OR-OFF (lv).pdf
LV - LEG - Law to reform the Law on notaries (2024) - OR-OFF (lv).pdf

marriage_explan:
Same-sex marriage in Latvia has been prohibited by Article 110 of the Constitution since 2006. Several attempts to legalise registered partnerships and other forms of legal protections for same-sex couples have failed since 1999. 
Following the *Coman-Hamilton v Romania* (2018) case, Latvia has granted residency rights to at least one same-sex couple married in Portugal.
civil_explan:
Several attempts to legalise registered partnerships and other forms of legal protections for same-sex couples have failed since 1999. 
In 2021, the Supreme Court referred to the Constitutional Court the case of a same-sex couple that is seeking the legal recognition and protection of their relationship.
In 2022, the Bill on a Civil Unions Law (*Bill No. 1380*) (2022) was introduced to recognise the right of same-sex couples to enter a civil union. Although there have been a few attempts to vote on it, they have proven fruitless either because the minimum number of MPs was not present or because it was excluded from the parliamentary agenda. Local media speculated that it would be difficult to obtain a majority in favour of recognising civil unions, at least before the end of the current legislature (in 2026). For this reason, there have been several activist efforts to collect signatures for a citizens' legislative initiative. However, the parliament has so far voted against taking them into consideration.
Moreover, there have been judicial decisions recognising same-sex couples as "couples" within the meaning of the Latvian Constitution. At least four judgments adopted by the Riga Administrative District Court have declared the existence of "family relations" between same-sex couples. According to an interview with the Minister of Justice, as of April 2023, the administrative court has already recognised 36 same-sex couples as families, and about 30 more cases have been filed or are being prepared. The Minister of Justice also declared that a package of several draft laws on same-sex partnerships is under preparation.
In November 2023, the Parliament passed legislation that would legally recognise same-sex couples. However, a group of 34 parliamentarians swiftly submitted a motion to the President requesting a postponement of the law's entry into force to hold a referendum on the matter instead. The bill's entry into force was reportedly suspended, allowing the group to attempt to collect the signatures required by law to proceed with the referendum. However, in January 2024, it was reported in Latvian media that they had not reached the required number of signatures, falling far short of the required minimum. Accordingly, that same month, the president enacted the *Law on the Reform of the Notary Law* (2024), which allows same-sex couples who "have a close personal relationship, a common household and the intention to mutually nurture and support each other" to formalise their relationship in a public deed signed before a notary. The law also specifies that such a "partnership" does not constitute a marriage in any case. On 1 July 2024, the law entered into force.

sources.original_official_filename: LI - LEG - Bill to legalise same-sex marriage (2023) - OR-OFF(de).pdf
LI - LEG - Registered Partnership Act (2011) - OR-OFF (de).pdf
LI - LEG - State Law Gazette No. 261 (2024) - OR-OFF (de).pdf
LI - LEG - Bill to legalise same-sex marriage (2023) - OR-OFF(de).pdf

marriage_explan:
Prior to the legalisation of same-sex marriage, polling indicated broad support among the public and several elected representatives of the Landtag for marriage equality following the adoption of such legislation in Germany in 2017 and Switzerland in 2021. 
In September 2021, a debate in the Landtag saw most representatives agree in principle to the legalisation of same-sex marriage, pending public consultations. 
Also, in 2021, the Head of State, Prince Hans-Adam II, reportedly told media outlets that he was not opposed to same-sex marriage being legalised but would use his authority to veto the law if it granted same-sex couples the right to joint adoption.
In September 2022, 15 MPs submitted a motion to introduce a bill legalising same-sex marriage. Given that the Liechtenstein parliament consists of 25 MPs, it has been reported as a sign that a majority favourable to same-sex marriage has already been secured. In November 2022, the motion was discussed in the plenary session and was passed by a 23–2 vote. Following this, a bill was introduced to amend three existing laws: the Marriage Act, the Partnership Act, and the Personal and Company Act. In March 2024, the parliament approved the *Bill Legalising Same-Sex Marriage* (2022) during its first reading, with 24 votes in favour and only one against. According to the bill, no further registered partnerships will be formed in Liechtenstein, though existing ones will still be acknowledged and may be converted to marriages through a straightforward process. In May 2024, the marriage law amendment bill passed its second reading in parliament, legalising same-sex marriage in Liechtenstein. The law came into effect on 1 January 2025.
civil_explan:
The *Law on Registered Partnership of Same-Sex couples* (2011) was passed unanimously in March 2011 by the Landtag, but challenged by a legally binding referendum in April. Over 68% of Lichtenstein's citizens voted in favour of the law, which came into effect in September of that year. The law confers limited protections to same-sex partners, and overtly denied couples the right to adoption or reproductive medical assistance under Article 25 until the State Court of Liechtenstein ruled in June 2021 that registered partners should have the right to adopt the children of their spouses.
In May 2024, the *Bill Legalising Same-Sex Marriage* (2023) was passed by the Parliament. The law stipulates that no new civil unions will be registered, but existing ones will continue to be recognised and may be converted into marriages upon the request of the couples involved.

sources.original_official_filename: LT - LEG - Bill on civil unions (2022) - OR-OFF (lt).pdf
LT - JUD - Constitutional Court KT21 N5 (2025) - OR-OFF (lt).pdf

marriage_explan:
Same-sex marriage in Lithuania has been banned by Article 38 of the Constitution since 1992, as well as by Article 3(12) of the Lithuanian Civil Code (2000). 
On 11 January 2019, however, in compliance with the *Coman-Hamilton v Romania* (2018) ruling of the Court of Justice of the European Union, the Constitutional Court ruled that same-sex spouses of Lithuanian residents married abroad must be granted residency permits (*Decision No KT3-N1/2019*).
In July 2023, a Vilnius District Court denied a request from a same-sex couple to register their marriage. This decision was appealed by the couple in August 2023 before the Vilnius Regional Court. A similar request was filed in April 2023 for the recognition of same-sex civil unions.
civil_explan:
In 2021, a *Bill on Partnerships* (2021) was introduced in the Lithuanian Parliament to recognise same-sex couples' right to enter a civil partnership. However, this bill was eventually rejected and dropped. Moreover, the President of Lithuania announced his intention to veto the law had the bill been approved.
After the rejection of the Bill on Partnerships in May 2022, the *Bill on Civil Unions* (2022) was introduced in the Lithuanian parliament with a gender-neutral definition, opening the possibility for same-sex civil unions. Although it has been reported that this bill is not as comprehensive as local CSOs would have preferred, it was described as an important step forward. 
In parallel, in April 2023, a group of same-sex couples filed a request before the local courts to have their civil partnerships officially recognised. However, in late April, news outlets reported that the District Court of the City of Vilnius had rejected their cases on the basis that, currently, there is no law on civil partnerships.
The Bill on Civil Unions (2022) passed the first stage of the legislative process in May 2023. However, in March 2024, local sources reported that the Seimas had not included a discussion on this bill in its agenda for Spring.
In April 2025, the Constitutional Court ruled in its *Judgment No. KT21-N5* (2025) that civil laws that prevent same-sex couples from entering a same-sex civil union are unconstitutional. It also mandated the legislative power to establish a "comprehensive legal regulation" that provides sufficient protection for "unmarried couples whose common life is based on the content of permanent or long-term family relationships (...) covering both property and other aspects inseparable from family life". Thus, even though this judgment legalised same-sex civil unions, a more specific set of rules is needed to provide adequate protection for them.
After the Constitutional Court's resolution, discussions on how to comply with its order ensued among parliamentarians. As of April 2025, several bills -ranging from the complete abolition of civil unions to different degrees of recognition of unmarried couples' rights- have been tabled by different political forces, with no clear solution in sight. In the meantime, some district courts have reportedly started recognising same-sex couples.

marriage_explan:
In France, the Law Opening Marriage to Same-Sex Couples (*Law No. 2013-404*) (2013) amended the *Civil Code* to legalise same-sex marriage. The first reported marriage taking place between two non-resident men on 27 September 2013. This makes Mayotte one of the only Muslim-majority territories in the world to allow same-sex marriage.
In March 2022, two men filed a lawsuit against the mayor of the town of Kani Kéli for repeatedly refusing to solemnise their union. The mayor has reportedly stated that the refusal is so as not to upset the social mores and traditions of his constituency. As there is no clause in French law permitting conscientious objections by civil servants, the mayor is reportedly liable for a 75,000 Euro fine or five years' imprisonment, though the details of the court case itself are unclear.
civil_explan: Decree No. 2006-1807 (2006) extended the application of the French Civil Solidarity Pact to Mayotte. *Law No. 99-944* (1999) confers some legal recognition to same-sex couples outside of marriage.

marriage_explan:
Same-sex marriage has been legalised in all subnational jurisdictions in Mexico. The process began in 2009 when Mexico City first allowed same-sex marriage (in force since 2010) and concluded in 2022 when Tamaulipas joined the list of regions offering this legal protection.
In June 2015, the Supreme Court of Mexico declared that bans on marriage equality were unconstitutional and required the recognition of same-sex marriages conducted in other states. However, this decision did not lead to a nationwide legalisation of same-sex marriages. Instead, such marriages have been permitted on a case-by-case basis, typically through judicial rulings, in states without specific legislation for such unions.
In May 2019, Mexico's Minister of Foreign Affairs announced that all Mexican consulates would enable citizens to marry regardless of their gender.
civil_explan: There is no federal law providing for civil unions. However, such unions and other forms of registered partnerships are recognised in several jurisdictions within Mexico.

marriage_explan: In 2019 the Supreme Court of Justice ruled to allow same-sex marriages in the State of Aguascalientes, a move celebrated by the National Human Rights Council.

In July 2022, a federal judge ordered the Congress of Durango to consider a same-sex marriage bill. The ruling mandated legislators to act line with Supreme Court jurisprudence.

MX - JUD - Jalisco Unconstitutionality Action No. 28 (2015) - OR.OFF (en).pdf

marriage_explan:
As a result of a constitutional challenge brought forward by the National Human Rights Commission, in 2016 the Mexican Supreme Court issued its decision in *Unconstitutionality Action No. 28/2015* (2016), invalidating several articles of the Civil Code of Jalisco that referred to "a man and a woman" when regulating marriage. These included articles 260, 258, and 267 bis. Shortly after Jalisco recorded its first solemnisation of a same-sex marriage.
In April 2022 Articles 258, 260 and 267 of the *Civil Code* (2022) were amended to formally codify same sex marriage into law.
civil_explan:
Same-sex civil unions were legalised by the *Free Cohabitation Act* (2013), which entered into effect in 2014. 
However, in 2018, the Supreme Court of Mexico struck down the law due to shortcomings in the parliamentary proceedings under which the law was approved. By then, same-sex marriages had become legal after the Supreme Court issued its decision for *Unconstitutionality Action No. 28/2015* (2016).

sources.original_official_filename: MX - LEG - Estado de Mexico Civil Code (2002) - OR-OFF (es).pdf
MX - LEG - Legislative Decree No. 103 Mexico State's Same Sex Marriage (2022) - OR-OFF(es).pdf

marriage_explan:
In 2020 five same-sex couples were granted an amparo (court order) permitting them to get married. Due to the Covid-19 pandemic the first of these couples was not married until March 2021. However, each subsequent same-sex marriage in the state required an amparo, as no legislation formally permititng such unions had been passed. Also in 2021, several MPs introduced a bill to recognise same-sex marriage by repealing the ban in the *Civil Code* (2002). Addittionaly, it would repeal Article 4.7, Part IX of the Civil Code, which lists "bisexuality" as grounds to prohibit marriage.
Finally, on 11 October 2022, the Congress of the State of Mexico voted 49-12 with six abstentions to pass *Legislative Decree No. 103* (2022) legalizing same-sex marriage and concubinage, becoming the 29th state to modify its Civil Code to make same-sex unions valid.

marriage_explan: Same-sex marriage was legalised after amendments to the Family Code were announced in the *Official Periodical of the State of Michoacán* (2016).
civil_explan: Michoacán’s congress unanimously voted to legalise civil unions for same-sex couples on 9 September 2015, publishing the amendments to the *Family Code* in the State Gazette on 30 September of the same year.

MX - LEG - Morelos State Bulletin Marriage Reform (2016) - OR-OFF (es).pdf

marriage_explan: Same-sex marriage was legalised after the *Official Periodical of the State of Morelos* publicised amendments to the State Constitution on 4 July 2016.
civil_explan: On 4 July 2016, amendments to the Morelos Civil Code were announced in the *State Gazette* to allow for same-sex couples to enter into civil unions.

MX - LEG - Nayarit Civil Code (2015) - OFF (es).pdf

marriage_explan: After a number of amendments to the *Nayarit Civil Code*, same-sex marriage was formally recognised in 2015.
civil_explan: In 2015, when the State’s *Civil Code* was amended to allow for same-sex marriage, it was noted that civil unions for same-sex couples would also be permitted (locally referred to as “concubinato”).

sources.original_official_filename: MX - JUD - Nuevo Leon ruling on marriage (2019) - (es).pdf
MX-NLE - LEG - Civil Code Amendment SSU (2023) - OR-OFF(es).pdf

marriage_explan:
The Supreme Court of Justice of Mexico (SCJN) ruled in the *Action of Unconstitutionality No. 29/2018* (2019) that the definition of marriage in Nuevo León's legislation did not align with the fundamental principles outlined in the constitutional reform. The court stated that this legislation violated the prohibition of discrimination based on gender, sexual preferences, marital status, or any factors that undermine human dignity. This verdict was issued following numerous writs of amparo regarding same-sex marriage in lower courts. After the decision, at least two proposals were introduced in 2021 to amend the Civil Code and bring it in line with the verdict.
In June 2023, the Congress of Nuevo León approved a *Civil Code Amendment Bill* (2023) that ultimately enshrined same-sex marriage in the state's legislation.

sources.original_official_filename: MX - LEG - Oaxaca State Bulletin Marriage Reform (2019) - OR-OFF (es).pdf

marriage_explan: On 28 August 2019, the Oaxaca Congress approved a bill to amend the Civil Code. The amendment defined marriage as "a civil contract celebrated between two people, who come together to establish a life in common and provide each other with respect, equality, and mutual assistance". The law was enacted on the same month and gazetted in October 2019 (see *Official Gazette of Oaxaca*).

sources.original_official_filename: MX - LEG - Puebla Civil Code with marriage amendments (2020) - OR-OFF (es).pdf

marriage_explan:
In 2017, the Supreme Court of Justice declared Article 300 of the Civil Code of Puebla, which defines marriage as being between "a man and a woman", unconstitutional. However, in October 2019, the Congress of Puebla voted against reforming local legislation in order to render it consistent with the Supreme Court’s ruling. 
In November 2020, the Congress of Puebla finally approved amendments to Articles 294, 297, 298, and 300 of the *Civil Code*, which now provide for a gender-neutral definition of “marriage”.

In March 2021 a Federal judge ordered the state authorities to legislate in favour of same-sex marriage, as a bill had been pending on the matter since 2018. 
In November of that same year, the Congress approved a reform of the Civil Code (2009) to legalize same-sex marriage in Queretaro.

sources.original_official_filename: MX - LEG - Codigo Civil Quintana Roo (act a 2018) - OR-OFF (es).pdf

marriage_explan: The *Civil Code of the State of Quintana Roo* does not specify as a requirement that the marriage be celebrated between "a man and a woman". Based on this, authorities in Quintana Roo have allowed for same-sex marriages to be celebrated in the state. The first two marriages were solemnised in November 2011, but in 2012 the Director of the Civil Registry declared them null and void. That same year, the Undersecretary of Legal Affairs of the Government Secretariat of the State of Quintana Roo determined the validity of same-sex marriages under state legislation, settling the legal uncertainty generated.

sources.original_official_filename: MX - LEG - Family Code San Luis Potosi (2008) - OR-OFF (es).pdf
MX - LEG - Family Code San Luis Potosi (2008) - OR-OFF (es).pdf
MX - LEG - San Luis Potosi State Bulletin Marriage Reform (2019) - OR-OFF (es).pdf

marriage_explan: In 2019, several provisions of the *Family Code of San Luis Potosi* (2008) were amended to allow for same-sex marriages. See also: *Parliamentary Gazette* (2019).
civil_explan: Concurrent with the legalisation of same-sex marriage in 2019, Article 105 of the *Family Code for the State of San Luis Potosí* (2008) was also amended by removing the clause "man and woman" to define concubinage as the de facto union "between two people" through domestic cohabitation, sexual union, respect and reciprocal protection, with the tacit purpose of integrating a family with or without offspring.

MX - LEG - Sinaloa Decree no 646 (2021) - OR-OFF(es).pdf

sources.original_official_filename: MX - LEG - Sonora Family Code (2009) - OR-OFF(es).pdf
MX - LEG - Sonora Decree no 3 (2021) - OR-OFF(es).pdf

marriage_explan:
In 2019, two women were married through an amparo action and were able to register with the Institute for Social Security and Services of Sonora State Workers in 2021 through another amparo action. A couple of men had achieved the same in 2013 through the same legal remedy.
In 2021, the *Family Code of Sonora* (2007) was amended by *Decree No. 3* (2021) to legalise same-sex marriages.

sources.original_official_filename: MX - LEG - Opinion of the Reform of the Civil Code of Tabasco (2022) - OR-OFF(es).pdf
MX - LEG - Tabasco Civil Code as amended (2022) - OR-OFF(es).pdf

marriage_explan:
On 17 October 2022, the Ordinary Commission of Government and Constitutional Issues approved *Opinion of the Reform of the Civil Code of Tabasco* (2022) for the legalisation of same-sex marriage with 4 votes in favor and 2 abstentions. 
On 19 October 2022, the Tabasco Congress *approved the reform of the civil code* to legalize same-sex marriage in Tabasco, with 22 votes in favor, 6 against and 7 abstentions.

sources.original_official_filename: MX - LEG - Tamaulipas same-sex marriage dropped bill (2022) - OR-OFF(es).pdf
MX - LEG - Taumalipas Civil Code marriage amendment (2022) - OR-OFF(es).pdf

marriage_explan:
A *Bill* (2022) to approve same-sex marriage was discussed in the Congress of Tamaulipas in May 2022, but was rejected and dropped.
However, on 26 October 2022, the same Congress legalised same-sex marriage by passing the *Civil Code amendment* (2022), with 23 votes in favor, 12 against and one abstention. With the approval of equal marriage in Tamaulipas, this right became available in all states of Mexico.

sources.original_official_filename: MX - LEG - Tlaxcala Civil Code with marriage amendment (2020) - OR-OFF (es).pdf
MX - LEG - Tlaxcala Civil Union Law (2017) - OR-OFF (es).pdf

marriage_explan: On 8 December 2020, the Congress of Tlaxcala voted in favour of amending some articles of the state’s *Civil Code* to make them gender neutral, thereby legalising same-sex marriages.
civil_explan: Same-sex civil unions became legal under the *Law on Solidary Cohabitation* (2017), which granted same-sex couples some of the rights and obligations given to married couples.

sources.original_official_filename: MX - LEG - Decree No. 234 (2022) - OR-OFF(es).pdf
MX - LEG - Veracruz Civil Code (2020) - OR-OFF (es).pdf

marriage_explan:
Marriage equality was approved in Veracruz when a Federal judge ruled that provisions against same-sex marriage were unconstitutional, and that from 2 June 2021 all same-sex marriages were to be formally registered regardless of whether or not the state civil code had been amended to permit this. 
In June 2022, the Congress of the state of Veracruz approved *Decree No. 234* (2022) to legalise same-sex marriage. The law amends articles 75 and 77 of the state's Civil Code, changing the definition of marriage as "the union of a man and a woman" to "the union of two people through a civil contract".
civil_explan: The Veracruz *Civil Code* (1932) was amended in 2020 to include a gender-neutral provision on cohabitation providing for “the de facto union between two people, without there being a contract between them, that both are free from marriage and decide to share life to support each other”. The law further noted that couples entering such a union held "all the rights and obligations inherent to marriage”.

sources.original_official_filename: MX - LEG - Yucatan decree 413-2021 on marriage and concubinage (2021) - OR-OFF (es).pdf
MX - LEG - Yucatan decree 413-2021 on marriage and concubinage (2021) - OR-OFF (es).pdf
MX - JUR - National Supreme Court of Justice Judgment no. 27 2021 (2021) - OR-OFF (es).pdf
MX - JUR - National Supreme Court of Justice Judgment no. 27 2021 (2021) - OR-OFF (es).pdf

marriage_explan:
On 7 September 2021, the Yucatan constitution was amended to offer a gender-neutral definition of marriage, as outlined in *Decree No. 413* (2021) in the official state Gazette the previous day. The decree also gave legislators 180 days (until 6 March 2022) to amend relevant provisions in the Family Code and elsewhere to bring them into alignment with the constitutional change.
The amendment of the Constitution was voted twice, since on 15 July 2019, the Congress reejected the modification that would allow for equal marriage, casting its vote through secret ballot. On 18 August 2021, the National Supreme Court of Justice ruled in *judgment no. 27/2021* (2021) that the procedure had been unconstitutional and requested Yucatan's Congress to repeat the vote on the constitutional amendment nominally.
On 12 January 2022, the Plenary of the National Supreme Court of Justice was due to resolve the amparo appeal filed in 2019 by various civil society organisations against the failure of the State to reform secondary laws -such as the Family Code- to fully recognise equal marriage. However, the Court appointed a new magistrate to draft a new ruling due to lack of agreement. The resolution of this amparo is still pending. under the case with file no. 413/2020. Then, in March 2022, after 25 deputies of the LXIII legislature of the State Congress unanimously approved the changes in the Civil Registry Law and the Family Code of the State of Yucatan, same-sex marriage became a reality in Yucatan.
civil_explan:
On 7 September 2021, the Yucatan constitution was amended to offer a gender-neutral definition of "concubinage", or recognised cohabitation, as outlined in *Decree No. 413* (2021) in the official state Gazette the previous day.
The amendment of the Constitution was voted twice, since on 15 July 2019, the Congress rejected the aforementioned modification, casting its vote through secret ballot. On 18 August 2021, the National Supreme Court of Justice ruled in *judgment no. 27/2021* (2021) that the procedure had been unconstitutional and requested Yucatan's Congress to repeat the vote on the constitutional amendment nominally.

sources.original_official_filename: MX - LEG - Zacatecas Decree 42 on same-sex marriage (2021) - OR-OFF (es).pdf

marriage_explan:
Between February 2019 and July 2020, five municipalities within Zacatecas (Zacatecas City, Cuauhtémoc, Villanueva, Miguel Auza and Fresnillo) began issuing marriage certificates for same-sex couples, despite the State governor arguing that these unions would not be legally recognised.
The following year, on 14 December 2021, the Congress of Zacatecas passed a same-sex marriage law, which was published in state Gazette No. 104 as *Decree No. 42* (2021) on 29 December, the day before coming into force.
civil_explan: In the decade prior to the advent of marriage equality in the state, at least two bills to allow civil unions were introduced, though neither passed.

sources.original_official_filename: RU - JUD - ECHR Fedotova and others v Russia (2023) - OR-OFF(en).pdf
MD - LEG - Draft law for the conception of a national policy for the national preservation and consolidation of traditional spiritual and moral values (2024) - OR-OFF(ru).pdf

marriage_explan:
In February 2023, a same-sex couple sought to register their marriage with the Moldovan Public Services Agency. They cited the European Court of Human Rights decision of *Fedotova and others v Russia* (2023), which ruled that members of the Council of Europe must recognise and protect families formed by same-sex partners (although not necessarily by recognising equal marriage). However, their application was rejected at the administrative level, so the couple, along with other couples, filed a joint lawsuit against the Agency. In April 2024 the Rascani District Court rejected one of the five complaints brought to court. This marked the first decision among five cases of same-sex couples suing the State on this grounds.

In June 2024, MPs from the Victorie political party in Moldova introduced the *Draft bill for the conception of a national policy for the national preservation and consolidation of traditional spiritual and moral values* (2024). This bill essentially seeks to create a national policy of “protecting traditional spiritual and moral values”. Moreover, it mandates the government to submit other proposals to bring legislation in line with this national policy within 3 months of the bill's approval. The policies mentioned in the bill include the “preservation, strengthening and promotion of traditional family values” and the “protection of the institution of marriage as a union between a man and a woman”.

sources.original_official_filename: MC - LEG -  Law 1.481 relating to civil solidarity contracts (2019) - OR-OFF (fr).pdf

civil_explan: Monaco’s National Council voted unanimously to allow same-sex unions under the Law relating to Civil Solidarity Contracts (*Law No. 1,481*) (2019), which came into effect on 27 June 2020. It allows same-sex couples, as well as different-sex couples, siblings, or other pairs who live together, to take on some of the legal benefits of shared property ownership and financial responsibility, pension and inheritance rights, and illness cover. However, the law does not provide cohabitants with the same rights as married couples and explicitly notes that “the legal regime of the contract has no effect on the rules of filiation, parental authority and the rights of the child”.

sources.original_official_filename: ME - LEG - Official Gazette of Montenegro, No. 67.2020 proclaiming civil unions (2020) - OR-OFF (cs).pdf

civil_explan:
After being rejected in 2019, a bill granting rights to same-sex couples (not including adoption) was passed in 2020. On July 1, Law on Life Partnership of Persons of the Same Sex (*Law No. 01-1337/2*) (2020) was enacted and entered into force in July 2021 (a year after its publication).
In January 2024 it was reported that a new bill aimed at ensuring equal rights to same-sex civil unions was being prepared. ILGA World is currently gathering more information on this development. Please come back shortly.

sources.original_filename: UK - LEG - Marriage (Same Sex Couples) (Overseas Territories) Bill (2022) - OR (en).pdf

marriage_explan: In July 2022 the *Marriage (Same Sex Couples) (Overseas Territories) Bill* (2022) was introduced in the United Kingdom's House of Lords. If passed by both chambers of the Parliament, the bill will require the Governors of six British Overseas Territories (including Montserrat), to legalise same-sex civil marriage within six months.

sources.original_official_filename: NA - LEG - Marriage Amendment (Bill) (2023) - OR-OFF(en).pdf

sources.original_filename: NA - EXE - Motivation Tabling Statement Marriage Bill (2024) - OR(en).pdf

marriage_explan:
On 16 May 2023, the Supreme Court of Namibia issued a ruling in *Digashu et al. v. Government of the Republic of Namibia* (2023) recognising same-sex marriages performed abroad between citizens and foreign spouses as legal. Foreign spouses of the two couples that brought the case forward were denied residency permits under the *Immigration Control Act* (1993) as they were unable to be officially recognised as “spouses”. The Supreme Court ruled that the provisions in the Immigration Control Act were discriminatory and violated the constitutional protections of dignity and equality and directed the government to recognise same-sex marriages validly concluded abroad. In late May, the government reportedly began conducting a legal assessment of the landmark ruling before deciding on a course of action. However, on 6 June 2023, the Prime Minister of Namibia, Saara Kuugongelwa-Amadhila, announced that the Government would introduce a bill to the National Assembly to restrict the recognition of same-sex marriages, even if solemnised in countries where such marriages are legal.
However, soon after that, in July 2023, lawmakers from the SWAPO Party of Namibia submitted two private member bills that would prohibit same-sex marriages. The *Definition of Spouse (Bill)* (2023) invokes Articles 81 and 45 of the Namibian Constitution to contradict the Supreme Court decision to define the definition of "spouse" as "a person, being one half of a legal union between a man and a woman of the opposite sex of that person". The other bill, the *Marriage Amendment (Bill)* (2023), would also define the term "spouse" to only include those of the "opposite sex", in addition to introducing a clause that would prohibit same-sex marriages and not recognise foreign same-sex marriages as valid. Any person found to solemnise such marriages or "witness, promote or propagate" same-sex marriages would also be guilty of committing an offence, being liable, upon conviction, to a fine or to imprisonment. Both bills reportedly passed the National Assembly vote with minimal amendments, and on 19 July 2023, the National Council, Namibia's upper house, reportedly passed both bills. Since September 2023, both bills have been awaiting final approval from the President.
In addition, the *Amendments to the Civil Registration and Identification Bill* (2023) was also introduced to define "spouses" as "a genetically born man of full age" and "a genetically born woman of full age".
On 2 July 2024 the Ministry of Home Affairs tabled a *bill* which would repeal existing marriage legislation and replace it with a law defining marriage as only between persons of the "opposite sex". In December 2024, the law was enacted a the Marriage Act 2024 (2024). Separately, a private member’s bill introduced in 2024 also sought to ban same-sex marriages. However, in March 2025, President Nangolo Mbumba declined to sign this private member’s bill, preventing it from becoming law.
civil_explan:
In *Chairperson of the Immigration Selection Board v. Frank and Another* (2001) two women (one Namibian and one German) sought recognition for their relationship after getting married abroad. The Supreme Court ruled against them on the basis that they fall outside of the scope of Section 14 of the *Constitution* (1990), though the law there does not expressly define marriage as being solely between a man and a woman. However, the court did rule that the German spouse should be issued with a residency permit to stay permanently in Namibia with her spouse.
In January 2018, the Namibian government agreed to allow the same-sex partner of a Namibian man to remain in the country on a visitor’s permit just before his temporary work visa expired. The couple had applied to the High Court to issue a certificate of identity that would recognise the non-citizen partner as the spouse. The couple later merged their case with that of a lesbian couple, jointly seeking recognition in *Seiler-Lilles v. Government of the Republic of Namibia and others* (2021).
In January 2022 the High Court Main Division ruled against the two same-sex binational couples seeking recognition and residency rights in. The three High Court judges stated that they could not overturn the 2001 Supreme Court precedent, but unanimously condemned the ruling as being discriminatory and outdated. The case is due to go to the Supreme Court for appeal and is still pending as of April 2023.
In March 2022 the Supreme Court ruled in a separate case, *Castaneda v. Minister of Home Affairs and Immigration and Another* (2022), that the Department of Home Affairs must consider the residency application of a man from Spain whose husband and child are Namibian citizens, but fell short of mandating the approval of the residency application.

sources.original_official_filename: NE - JUD - SC - Adheep Pokhrel and Tobias Volz. v. Ministry of Home Affairs, Department of Immigration (2023) - OR (ne).pdf
sources.translated_filename: NE - Court - Adheep Pokhrel - TR(en).pdf

marriage_explan:
On 3 May 2023, in the case of *Adheep Pokhrel and Tobias Volz vs Ministry of Home Affairs, Department of Immigration* (2023), the Supreme Court of Nepal issued an interim order directing the government to establish a transitional mechanism for the registration of marriages for same-sex couples and other non-traditional heterosexual couples. The order recognises marriage rights based on gender identity and sexual orientation, calling for necessary amendments to the provisions related to marriage within the Civil Code. The court also mandated the creation of a separate register of marriages for sexual and gender minority communities. The Court's order allows same-sex couples to register their marriages while awaiting potential legislative changes legally. However, in July 2023, the media reported that the Kathmandu District Court had refused to register a same-sex marriage on the grounds that since the Supreme Court's order was addressed to the government, the lower courts were not bound to comply with it. Subsequently, in October 2023, the Patan High Court reportedly upheld the decision of the Kathmandu District Court denying the marriage registration of Maya Gurung and Surendra Pandey. However, it was reported a month later, in November 2023, that authorities in Dordi in the district of Lamjung, where they are both from, agreed to follow the interim court order and officially register their marriage, making it the first-ever instance of same-sex marriage in Nepal. 
Note: As of April 2025, the status of full and operational marriage equality for same-sex couples in Nepal remains unclear. This situation is evolving. Please check back for updates shortly.

sources.original_official_filename: NL - LEG - Act on Opening Up of Marriage (2000) - OR-OFF(nl).pdf
NL - LEG - Article 1-80(a)-(e), Book 1 of the Civil Code - OR-OFF(nl).pdf
NL - EXE - Royal Decree - Act on Opening Up of Marriage (2000) - OR-OFF(nl).pdf

marriage_explan:
Article 30 of the *Act on the Opening up of Marriage* (2000, effective 2001) states “[a] marriage can be contracted by two persons of different-sex or of the same-sex”, thereby making the Netherlands the first country in the world to enact same-sex marriage laws. The Act amended Book 1 of the Dutch Civil Code. It was published in the Official Journal of the Netherlands on 11 January 2001 (Staatsblad, 2001, nr. 9). On the basis of art. IV of this Act, the *Royal Decree of 20 March 2001* (published in Staatsblad, 2001, nr. 145) specified (in its art. 2) that the Act on the Opening Up of Marriage would enter into force on 1 April 2001. The first same-sex marriages were celebrated at the stroke of midnight at the start of that day.
At the time, the country's Prime Minister Wim Kok reportedly stated that should the heir to the Dutch throne wish to marry a person of the same sex, they would need to forego their titles as no new royal heirs could be born in such a union. However, in 2021 Prime Minister Mark Rutte clarified to Parliament that the next in line to the throne could indeed enter a same-sex marriage, provided the union was approved by Parliament, as all royal unions must be.
civil_explan: Co-existing with same-sex marriage, Article 1:80(a)-(e), Book 1 of the *Civil Code* confers comprehensive protections to both same-sex and differentsex civil partners. These unions are virtually equivalent to marriage.

FR - LEG - Civil Solidarity Pact Law (PACS), Law 99-944 (1999) - OR-OFF (fr).pdf
FR - LEG - Civil Code Article 143 amendment on same sex marriage (2013) - OR-OFF (fr).pdf

marriage_explan: In France, the Law Opening Marriage to Same-Sex Couples (*Law No. 2013-404*) (2013) amended the *Civil Code* to legalise same-sex marriages. This law applies to New Caledonia.

NZ - LEG - Civil Union Act (2004) - OR-OFF (en).pdf
NZ - LEG - Marriage Act (1955 as amended in 2018) - OFF (en).pdf

civil_explan: The *Civil Union Act* (2004) provides for civil unions, available to same-sex or different-sex couples.

marriage_explan: It was reported in January 2023 that the President of Niger, Mohamed Bazoum, spoke on the "La Voie du Sahel" radio station about the need to reform the country's criminal code and that he had begun work on forming a multi-disciplinary panel to do just that. Bazoum noted specifically that "in the future Penal Code, there will be a whole section dedicated to homosexuality." He indicated that the new Penal Code would criminalise same-sex sexual acts between adults, but notably also that any participants in same-sex marriages could be subjected to a punishment of "10 years of criminal imprisonment to life imprisonment or the death penalty."

sources.original_official_filename: US - JUD (SUP) - Obergefell v Hodges (2014) - OR-OFF (en).pdf

marriage_explan: The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands adopted same-sex marriage on 29 June 2015 following the US Supreme Court case on *Obergefell v Hodges* (2015). The Attorney General of the islands, Edward Manibusan, declared that the territory is bound by that ruling.

sources.translated_filename: NO - LEG - Marriage Act Amendment (2009) - TR (en).pdf
NO - LEG - Act 40 on Registered partnerships (1993) - TR (en).pdf

marriage_explan: Chapter 1, Section 1 of the *Marriage Act* (1993), amended in 2008 (in force since January 2009), states that “[t]wo persons of opposite sex or of the same-sex may contract marriage”.
civil_explan:
In 1993, with the enactment of the Law on Registered Partnerships (*Act No. 40*) (1993), Norway became the second country in the world (after Denmark) to legalise same-sex registered partnerships. 
With the enactment of same-sex marriage in 2009, couples who had entered into registered partnerships were given the possibility of modifying their civil status to marriage, but no new registered partnerships can be formalised.

sources.original_filename: PA - JUD -  CSJ Edicto 1105 (2021) - OR(es).pdf
PA - JUD - SC - Ruling No. 1042-16 SSU (2023) - OR-OFF(es).pdf

marriage_explan:
The Supreme Court of Justice rejected in *edict 1105* (2021) an amparo action aimed for the Court to decide upon the constitutionality of the rejection of the Electoral Tribunal to recognize the marriage of two men who were previously married in Colombia.
On 16 February 2023, the Supreme Court of Justice issued its *Decision No. 1042-16* (2023) concerning a constitutional challenge against three provisions of the Family Code that define marriage as between a "man and a woman" and explicitly prohibit same-sex marriage. The Court held that the legal norms were not unconstitutional on the grounds that it was justified to privilege heterosexual unions that establish families, reproduce and ensure the continuity of society. Furthermore, the Court stated that the "differential treatment" was based on the immanent purpose of the classical marriage institution and "not on the sexual propensities of individuals".

sources.original_official_filename: PE - LEG - PL 525 (2021) - OR-OFF (es).pdf

PE - JUD - CC - SCJ of Lima Ruling No. 931 2020 (2023) - OR-OFF(es).pdf

marriage_explan:
In December 2016, March 2019 and August 2019, the National Registry of Identification and Civil Status (RENIEC) was ordered to recognise and register same-sex marriages celebrated abroad. 
In 2017, a same-sex marriage bill was introduced, but failed to pass.
In 2021, several MPs introduced *Bill No. PL-525* (2021), which would amend the Civil Code to define marriage as the union between two "persons", thus allowing same-sex marriage. This bill was defeated in January 2023.
In 2022, the Constitutional Court rejected the petition of a couple of two women married in the USA to get their marriage legally recognised in Peru.
In July 2023, the Fourth Constitutional Chamber of the Superior Court of Justice of Lima issued a ruling in *Case No. 00931-2020* (2023), directing RENIEC to register the marriage of a same-sex couple conducted in Argentina. The Court chose not to enforce Article 234 of the Civil Code, which defines marriage as "between a man and a woman", as it deemed it inconsistent with the equality and non-discrimination principles in the constitution and international agreements. While this ruling establishes a significant precedent for marriage equality's legal acknowledgment, it doesn't alter the substance or validity of Article 234.
Subsequently, in September 2023, a congresswoman introduced the Bill on Equal Marriage (*Bill No. 5819*) (2023). This bill would amend Article 234 of the Civil Code to define marriage in gender-neutral terms as the "voluntarily agreed union between two persons", which, if passed, would legalise same-sex marriage.
civil_explan:
Under Article 6(2) of *Supreme Decree No. 220-2020-EF* (2020), same-sex partners of health professionals who died amidst the Covid-19 pandemic were explicitly included among the beneficiaries of financial aid granted to surviving partners.
In August 2022 *Bill No. 02803/2022-CR* (2022) was introduced into Congress to legalise civil unions for same-sex couples. 
In July 2023, *Bill No. 05584/2022-CR* (2023) to recognise civil unions between same-sex couples was introduced in Congress. The bill, like the one presented in 2022, expressly excludes the right to second parent adoption.

marriage_explan: In September 2019 the Supreme Court ruled to deny a petition to declare the prohibition on same-sex marriage unconstitutional in *Jesus Nicardo M. Falcis, III v. Civil Registrar General* (2019), indicating instead that it was a matter for the legislature. A motion for the court to reconsider was subsequently "denied with finality" in December 2019, per an official *notice* circulated to media outlets. In November 2024, Congress received a bill allowing same-sex partners to make medical decisions for each other through the Right To Care (RTC) card program. The Department of Health would oversee applications for health care proxies. Under the proposal, a designated partner could access medical records and make decisions on their partner’s behalf, with priority unless stated otherwise. Healthcare providers would be required to follow the proxy’s decisions but would not be held liable for them.
civil_explan:
In July of 2022, *S.B. 449* (2022) was submitted to the 19th Congress of the Philippines to recognise civil partnerships for couples of the opposite or same sex. Another similar bill, *H.B. 6782*(2023) was filed in the 19th Congress in January 2023.
In April 2024, Bill *H.B. 10206* (2024), titled An Act Instituting A Property Regime for Cohabiting Same-Sex Partners and for Other Purposes, was introduced. This bill aims to protect same-sex couples' property rights.

PL - LEG - Bill No U87 on civil unions (2024) - OR-OFF (pl).pdf
PL - LEG - Bill No U88 to implement the law on civil unions (2024) - OR-OFF (pl).pdf

marriage_explan:
Same-sex marriage is not allowed in Poland, and couples married abroad are not recognised. For instance, in 2022 a couple married in Portugal who litigated to get their marriage recognised in Poland got their application rejected by Polish authorities and, eventually, by the Supreme Administrative Court. However, in this case the Supreme Administrative Court reportedly declared that, although currently existing legislation only allows for marriages between a man and a woman, another regulation would not necessarily be contrary to the Polish Constitution.
In November 2023, media reported that the Supreme Administrative Court of Poland had asked for a Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) preliminary ruling on whether EU Member States must recognise a same-sex marriage legally celebrated in another EU Member State, even if the former's legislation does not allow such a union. In the case referred to the CJEU by the Supreme Administrative Court, a couple formed by a Polish man and a Polish-German man had married in Germany and had applied for the recognition of their marriage in Poland. So far, the CJEU has only ruled that same-sex marriages celebrated in an EU Member State must be recognised in the rest of EU States only for residence purposes (for instance, when a EU citizen marries a person of their same sex who is not an EU citizen and they ask for the permission to reside in the EU Member State of origin of their partner). For this reason, a new EU ruling could have wide implications for same-sex marriages throughout the European Union, as it could potentially force Member States that don't allow -or even ban- same-sex marriages to admit their validity in their own jurisdictions, as long as they were legally celebrated in another EU Member State.
civil_explan:
In December 2023, the European Court of Human Rights condemned Poland in the case Przybyszewska and others v. Poland (*Application No. 11454/17 and others*) (2023). In particular, the Court in Strasbourg found that the Polish State had failed in its duty to ensure a specific legal framework for the recognition and protection of same-sex partnerships. This failure resulted in the applicant couples being unable to regulate fundamental aspects of their lives and violated their right to respect for their private and family life. Following this ruling, the newly formed Polish government (composed of several opposition parties that had already voiced their support for advancing LGBTI+ rights) announced its intention to introduce a bill to recognise same-sex civil unions.
Thus, in October 2024 the Government presented its Bill on civil unions (*Bill No. U87*) (2024), which allows for the legal recognition of couples as civil unions irrespective to the gender of its members. In particular, Article 2 establishes that a "civil union is established when two individuals make a mutual declaration before the head of the civil registry office to enter into such a union". It would also allow same-sex couples legally married in another country to be recognised as a civil union in Poland.
At the same time, the Government presented its Bill to implement the Law on Civil Unions (*Bill No. U88*) (2024), which modifies several laws to adapt the Polish legal landscape to the new civil unions and grant them rights and obligations.

marriage_explan:
Same-sex marriage in Romania has been expressly banned by Article 227(1) of the Civil Code since 2009. 
In June 2018, the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) issued a decision in "Relu Adrian Coman and others v. [General Inspectorate for Immigration and the Ministry of Internal Affairs] (*Case C-673/16*) (2018), rulling in favour of Adrian Coman, a Romanian citizen who—with support from the Romanian group ACCEPT—had filed a lawsuit before a Romanian court, seeking recognition of his marriage to Claibourn Hamilton (an American citizen) which had been celebrated in Belgium. The CJEU ruled that EU Member States were required to recognise same-sex marriages conducted in another EU Member State for the purpose of residency rights. In light of this decision, in September 2019, the Constitutional Court of Romania ruled that the State must grant residency rights to same-sex spouses of EU citizens and that same-sex couples enjoy the same rights to a private and family life as different sex couples.
In July 2023, the Romanian Ministry of Internal Affairs released *a draft amendment* to supplement the Emergency Ordinance on the Regime of Aliens in Romania (*GEO No. 194*) (2002) and enable family members of Romanian citizens "who have established a family life in another EU member state", to apply for a visa for family reunification (i.e. same-sex partners/spouses). In response to rumours that this amendment was "a disguised legalisation of the recognition of same-sex marriages or civil unions in Romania", the Ministry issued *a Press Release* clarifying the proposal in the following terms: "this draft law does not regulate the recognition of same-sex marriages or civil conventions on Romanian territory and other rights deriving from this recognition. The draft law is an implementation in the national legislation of the legal provisions existing at the EU level, only regarding the free movement of persons. The implementation of these provisions is a mandatory condition for Romania, following the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) of 5 June 2018 in case C-673/16, and failure to comply with it makes it possible to initiate an infringement procedure that can end with the conviction of Romania by the European court".
civil_explan:
Several bills aiming to regulate same-sex civil partnerships have failed in the last few years. 
In 2018, the National Council for Combating Discrimination introduced a bill (*Pl-x No. 662/2018*) (2018) that would allow couples who cannot or do not want to marry to formally register their consensual union with civil status officers. The initiative was rejected in 2021 by the Chamber of Deputies.
In May 2023, the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) condemned Romania in the case *Buhuceanu and others v. Romania* (2023) for violating the right to respect for the private and family life of several couples, as it failed in its obligation to establish some system to adequately recognise and protect same-sex relationships. However, in August 2023, the Romanian government formally communicated its decision to challenge this ruling before the Grand Chamber of the ECHR.
In July 2023, the Romanian the Ministry of Internal Affairs released *a draft amendment* to supplement the Emergency Ordinance on the Regime of Aliens in Romania (*GEO No. 194*) (2002) and enable family members of Romanian citizens "who have established a family life in another EU member state", to apply for a visa for family reunification (i.e. same-sex partners/spouses). In response to rumours that this amendment was "a disguised legalisation of the recognition of same-sex marriages or civil unions in Romania", the Ministry issued *a Press Release* clarifying the proposal in the following terms: "this draft law does not regulate the recognition of same-sex marriages or civil conventions on Romanian territory and other rights deriving from this recognition. The draft law is an implementation in the national legislation of the legal provisions existing at the EU level, only regarding the free movement of persons. The implementation of these provisions is a mandatory condition for Romania, following the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) of 5 June 2018 in case C-673/16, and failure to comply with it makes it possible to initiate an infringement procedure that can end with the conviction of Romania by the European court".

marriage_explan: The *Law of the Russian Federation on the Amendment of the Constitution of the Russian Federation* (2020) amended the Constitution to ban same-sex unions. It entered into force in 2021.
civil_explan:
The *Law of the Russian Federation on the Amendment of the Constitution of the Russian Federation* (2020) amended the Constitution to ban same-sex unions. It entered into force in 2021. 
That same year, the European Court of Human Rights ruled in *Fedotova and others v. Russia* (2021) that Russia must offer some sort of formal and legal recognition to same-sex partners. According to the Court, by failing to justify why there was a complete lack of recognition, Russia violated the European Convention of Human Rights.


On June 11, Russian President Vladimir Putin signed laws on non-enforcement of judgments of the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR) in the Russian Federation after March 15, the day Russia filed an application to withdraw from the Council of Europe. Part of these latest laws were seen to be in response to the ECtHR's Chamber judgment of Fedotova v. Russia that urged Russia to have some sort of partnership/recognition for same-sex couples.

marriage_explan:
In August 2022, the Singaporean Prime Minister announced plans during his *National Day Rally Speech* (2022) to repeal Section 377A of the Penal Code, which criminalises consensual same-sex sexual activity. However, in the same speech, he announced that the government would also amend the constitution to "safeguard the institution of marriage" defined as an union between a man and a woman.
In October 2022, the "Amendment No. 3 to the Constitution of the Republic of Singapore" (*Bill No. 32*) (2022) was introduced for its first reading in Parliament. It will incorporate a new Article 156, titled "Institution of Marriage", to protect the current heterosexual definition of marriage, as well as laws and policies based on this definition, from any challenge of unconstitutionality.

Same-sex marriages cannot be solemnised in Sint Maarten. However, under Article 40 of the Statute of the Kingdom of the Netherlands (1954), Constituent Countries must abide by many of the laws passed in the Netherlands. Thus, Sint Maarten must register same-sex marriages performed legally in parts of the Netherlands and its Constituent Countries.

marriage_explan:
In March 2022, the Ombudswoman filed a lawsuit before Slovakia's Constitutional Court to demand the recognition of same-sex couples married abroad for residency purposes. 
Also in 2022, a Slovakian-Argentinian couple married in Argentina also turned to the Slovakian courts with a similar case, after the authorities refused to grant the Argentinean citizen a residence permit. In November of that year, the Regional Court of Žilina ruled in their favour, granting the Argentinean citizen the right to remain in Slovakia and declaring that the refusal to grant him permanent residence had been discriminatory, in accordance with the rules that allow foreign spouses of Slovak nationals to legally reside in the country's territory.
civil_explan:
In October 2021, a draft law for same-sex partnerships was rejected in its second reading by the National Council of the Slovak Republic. Its aim was to improve the legal situation of these couples and their children.
In August 2022, the Progressive Slovakia party introduced *Bill no. 1124* (2022) to legally recognize partnerships irrespective of the sex of the persons forming them, although it is unclear if it has been dropped already. Another bill with the same aim was introduced by the Freedom and Solidarity party, but it failed to pass.
In January 2023, the Ministry of Justice put forth the *Act on Fiduciary Declaration and Amendment of Certain Acts* (2023), aiming to address the circumstances of unmarried couples, including same-sex pairs. The bill aimed to establish a procedure, facilitated by a notary public, where an individual could designate a fiduciary to act on their behalf in various life situations, encompassing matters such as inheritance, guardianship, and health information access. By April 2023, the finalised version reached the National Council. However, this proposed law was criticised by activists as an inadequate substitute for true recognition of same-sex couples. As the bill progressed through the legislative process in May 2023, the Ministry of Justice suggested its withdrawal.
Simultaneously, by April 2023, the *Bill on Life Partnerships* (2023) was presented to the National Council. This bill aims to permit both same-sex and different-sex couples to formalise their relationships through a civil union. 
Moreover, in May 2023, a group of thirty National Council members reportedly lodged a petition with the Constitutional Court, urging the court to call upon the parliament to align with international human rights standards by legally acknowledging and safeguarding same-sex couples through the official recognition of civil partnerships. However, in April 2024, local media reported that the Constitutional Court had dismissed it.

SI - LEG - The Act Amending Family Code (2023) - OR-OFF(sl).pdf

marriage_explan:
In June 2022, the Constitutional Court found in *Decisions 486-20 and 572-18* (2022) that the regulation to not allow same-sex couples the right to marry was discriminatory and that such discrimination cannot be justified by the "traditional" meaning of marriage as the union of husband and wife, nor by the special protection of families. Although same-sex couples were able to get married immediately after that judgment, in October 2022 the National Assembly amended the Family Code to legalise same-sex marriage (see *Press Release by Ministry of Labour*). However, the bill received a "suspensory veto" from the National Council, with a vote of 17 to 11, necessitating a further vote in the National Assembly. The National Council, as outlined in the Constitution of Slovenia, represents various social, economic, professional, and local interest groups in the country. It serves as a legislative corrective mechanism to the National Assembly, but does not have the authority to directly enact laws itself. Finally, on 18 October 2022, the National Assembly held an extraordinary legislative session where it passed the bill with a final vote, enshrining same-sex marriages and adoption in law.
Despite Article 90 of the Constitution prohibiting referendums on laws related to human rights and fundamental freedoms, representatives of the conservative group Coalition For Children submitted 30,600 citizens' signatures to the National Assembly calling for a referendum to repeal the amendments to the Family Code on same-sex marriage and adoption. The initiative was deemed inadmissible by a vote of National Assembly on 28 October 2022. Subsequently, the Constitutional Court issued *Decision U-I-398/22-16* (2023), confirming that the decision to reject the referendum was not unconstitutional.
On 31 January 2023, the *Act Amending the Family Code* (2023) came into effect in Slovenia. In February 2023, administrative units notified pre-existing same-sex partnerships that they could convert them into marriages. The conversion option is available until 31 July 2023.
civil_explan:
In 2005 the *Same-Sex Partnership Registration Act* (2005) allowed for same-sex couples to register their partnerships and take on limited rights to joint finances and property ownership.
This law was repealed with the adoption of the *Partnership Act* (in force since February 2017), which confers the rights to subsistence and maintenance, jointly owned property, occupancy, inheritance, and partner healthcare, but is silent on joint or second parent adoption provisions.
In January 2023, this law was repealed by the entry into force of the *Act Amending the Family Code* (2023), which approved marriage equality and removed civil unions from Slovenian legislation.

In July 2023, the Department of Home Affairs invited public comment on the *Draft Marriage Bill* (2022). The bill seeks to consolidate the three different acts governing marriage in South Africa, to recognise all types of intimate partnerships, irrespective of “gender, sex, or sexual orientation”. The bill would legislate and define monogamous marriages as being possible between any two adult prospective spouses, regardless of their sex or gender, while also allowing for polygamous marriages.

The *Civil Union Act* (2006) legalised civil unions for same-sex couples. This is the same piece of legislation that allows for same-sex marriage.
Also in 2006, the Constitutional Court ruled in *Gory v. Kolver NO and Others* that a requirement for a couple to be married in order for a surviving partner to inherit the estate of the deceased was unconstitutional, as same-sex marriage was not an option at the time of the ruling.

marriage_explan:
In May 2023, legislators introduced the Family Formation Right Act (2023), a bill to amend the Civil Code to recognise same-sex marriage.
In February 2025, LGBTI+ activists in South Korea filed a constitutional petition against civil legislation that bans same-sex marriage, after the Seoul Northern District Court rejected their request for a constitutional review.
civil_explan:
On January 7, 2022, the Seoul Administrative Court rendered a ruling in Case No. 2021-55456 (2022), opposing a same-sex couple's claims and asserting that there existed no legal foundation to extend protection to same-sex couples for the purpose of recognising them as "dependants" under the health insurance system. However, a significant shift occurred in February 2023, when South Korea's High Court reached a decision in *Case No. 2022-32797* (2023). In this landmark ruling, the High Court highlighted the absence of a rational justification for differentiating between same-sex and opposite-sex couples concerning the principle of equality in the context of extending insurance coverage to "dependants." In February 2020, the plaintiff had secured health insurance beneficiary status as the "de facto spouse" of his male partner. Following media exposure of this fact, the National Health Insurance Service (NHIS) retroactively rescinded the plaintiff's dependent qualification, asserting that the prior grant was an "error." The High Court therefore issued an order requiring the NHIS to reinstate coverage for partners within same-sex relationships. It was reported in March 2023 that the NHIS appealed against the 2023 High Court decision to the Supreme Court. On 18 July 2024, the Supreme Court affirmed the High Court's decision that the NHIS must extend dependent benefits to same-sex partners.
In April 2023, Congressman Yong Hae-in introduced the Life Partnership Bill (*Bill No. 2121647*) (2023) in the National Assembly. The aim of the bill is to legalise same-sex unions and includes amendments to 25 laws to provide social security protections for life partners similar to married couples. The bill is now under the review of the Legislation and Judiciary Committee.

sources.original_official_filename: LK - LEG - Gender Equality Bill (2024) - OR-OFF(en).pdf
LK - JUD - SC - SC SD 54 and SC SD 55 (2024) - OR-OFF(en).pdf

marriage_explan:
In May 2024, the *Gender Equality Bill* (2024) underwent its first reading in Parliament. The Bill’s main goal was to ensure equal opportunities to persons of different “gender identities” and that everybody enjoys “without discrimination based on […] gender identity the fundamental rights guaranteed by the Constitution”. However, two petitions were filed against it, arguing that it was contrary to the Constitution. 
In June 2024, the Supreme Court agreed with this position and ruled in *SC SD 54 and SC SD 55* (2024) that several clauses of the bill would go against public order and morality of the country in breach of Article 15 of the Constitution. In particular, the bill included the right to “private and family life” regardless of “gender identity”, which, in the Court's view, could be understood as including the right to same-sex marriage. Moreover, it also opposed the equal protection clause, which could be interpreted to allow the decriminalisation of consensual same-sex acts betwen adults. For this reasons, the court held that the bill would require both a special parliamentary majority and a referendum to be approved.

sources.original_official_filename: SR - JUD - case number no. 202303970 - (2025) - OR-OFF (nl).pdf

marriage_explan:
In February 2023, Suriname's Constitutional Court refused to recognise marriage of same-sex couple which was performed in Argentina. The court ruled that the ban on same-sex marriage does not violate the constitution and upheld the Central Bureau for Civil Affairs' refusal to register the marriage, highlighting that Suriname's Civil Code only permits marriage between a man and a woman. Although the court reportedly acknowledged "the outdated nature of the law", it did not find it discriminatory. 
However, on 14 February 2025, the Suriname First District Court ruled in *Case No. 202303970* (2025) that two same-sex couples who had married abroad shall be registered as married in the Central Bureau for Civil Affairs (CBB).

sources.original_official_filename: SE - LEG - Law on Registered Partnerships (Law 1994-1117) (1994) - OR-OFF (sv).pdf

marriage_explan: In 2009 the Swedish *Marriage Code* (1987) was amended to be gender-neutral, thereby legalising same-sex marriage.
civil_explan:
The Law concerning registered partnership (*Law No. 1994:1117*) (1995) legalised a specific form of formally registered legal union between two persons of the same gender: "Registered partnerships". Passed in 1994, the law came into effect on 1 January 1995. Prior to this law and since 1987, the Swedish legal framework had made "domestic partnerships" available for same-sex couples (i.e. cohabitation for unmarried/unregistered couples) as per the Law on homosexual cohabiting couples (Law No. 1987:813).
Registered partnerships involved most of the rules that apply to marriage. They were treated as a couple for tax, national insurance and other legal purposes. Until 2003, partners could not legally adopt or share joint custody of children. 
As of 1 May 2009, it is no longer possible to enter into partnerships in Sweden. The Law on Registered Partnership (1995) ceased to apply when marriage became available to couples regardless of gender.

sources.original_official_filename: TW - JUD (DC) - February No. 110-588 (2022) - OR-OFF(zh).pdf
TW - EXE - Ministry of Interior's Ordinance No. 1120240466 (2023) - OR-OFF(zh).pdf

marriage_explan:
In May 2017, the Constitutional Court of Taiwan ruled in *J.Y. Interpretation No. 748* (2017) that same-sex marriage is guaranteed by the constitutional right to equality. Taiwan legalised same-sex marriage after the legislature passed the *Act for Implementation of J.Y. Interpretation No. 748* (2019).
However, foreign nationals may only enter into same-sex marriage in Taiwan if their national law permits the same, as mandated by Article 46 of *Act Governing the Choice of Law in Civil Matters Involving Foreign Elements* (2010), which states that the "formation of a marriage is governed by the national law of each party". In January 2021, the judiciary proposed a *Bill to amend Article 46 and 63 of the 2010 Act* (2021), which will enable a Taiwan/foreign-national same-sex couple to marry in Taiwan regardless of the status of foreign law. In March 2021, in a case concerning a couple from Taiwan and Malaysia, the Taipei High Administrative Court ruled against this prohibition in *Qi Jia Wei v Taipei City Daan District Household Registration Office* (2021). The Court ordered the government to pass legislation to amend it and ruled that Taiwanese nationals should be entitled to enter into same-sex marriages whether their partner is Taiwanese or a foreign national. Moreover, in May 2021, in a case concerning a couple from Taiwan and Macau, the Taipei High Administrative Court ruled in *Ting Tse-yen and Leong Chin-fai v Taipei City Zhongzheng District Household Registration Office* (2021) that, as Taiwan was the habitual residence of the Macanese partner, Article 6 of the Act mandated that Taiwanese law be applied.
In December 2021, the Mainland Affairs Council announced it would amend the *Cross-Strait Act on Same-Sex Marriages* (2021) Articles 41-62 so that cross-strait same-sex marriages can apply to Article 46 of the Act Governing the Choice of Law in Civil Matters Involving Foreign Elements (2010). This will allow Taiwanese people to marry their same-sex spouses from the People's Republic of China. 
In February 2022, the Taoyuan District Court ruled in *Li Fang Yi v Lan Jia Jing* (2022) that Article 2 of the Act for Implementation of J.Y. Interpretation No. 748 (2019) can be applied to the divorce of a same-sex marriage. 
In July 2022, the Taipei High Administrative Court also ruled in favour of a cross-national same-sex couple to marry, this time from Japan and Taiwan. In January 2023, Taiwan’s Ministry of the Interior issued *Ordinance No. 1120240466* (2023) to notify local governments that the Act for Implementation of J.Y. Interpretation No. 748 (2019) applies to transnational same-sex couples. Same-sex couples with one Taiwanese and one foreign national can register their marriage, even if the foreign partner is from a jurisdiction where same-sex marriages are illegal. However, while this law applies to partners from Hong Kong and Macau, it doesn't apply to same-sex couples of Taiwanese and Chinese persons. Later, in September 2024, the Mainland Affairs Council announced that same-sex couples formed by Chinese and Taiwanese nationals and married in a third country would be allowed to register their marriage.
In August 2024, the Taipei High Administrative Court ruled in favour of a Chinese man who had married a Taiwanese man in the U.S., after the Immigration Department repeatedly denied his visa. The High Administrative Court ordered the Ministry of Interior to conduct a marriage interview for him in compliance with the ruling.
civil_explan:
Prior to 24 May 2019, when Taiwan legalised same-sex marriage, more than 80% of the population lived in jurisdictions where they could administratively register same-sex relationships. However, per the Department of Household Registration, same-sex partnership registrations (civil unions) can no longer be entered into by same-sex couples where one or both parties are Taiwanese citizens. Couples that entered into civil unions prior to the legalisation of same-sex marriage have the option of retaining their registration status or amending their partnership to marriage.
On 25 May 2020, the National Immigration Agency announced that same-sex couples who are both foreign nationals would be allowed to enter into same-sex partnership registrations.

sources.original_official_filename: TH - LEG - Draft Act for Amendment to the Civil and Commercial Code (2022) - OR-OFF(th).pdf
TH - EXE - National Human Rights Commission's Statement on Equal Marriage Bill (2022) - OR-OFF (th).pdf
TH - LEG - Marriage Equality Bill (2023) - OR-OFF(th).pdf

marriage_explan:
In November 2021, the Constitutional Court ruled that Article 1448 of the *Civil and Commercial Code* (1925), which defines marriage as being "between a man and a woman", was not unconstitutional after a same-sex couple sought and failed to register their union the previous year. The Court, however, instructed the government to implement legislation to protect people from discrimination on the basis of their gender identity.
In June 2022, the Cabinet approved the *Draft Act to Amend the Civil and Commercial Code* (2022), commonly referred to as the "Marriage Equality Bill". This proposed legislation aimed to modify the Civil and Commercial Code by revising the marriage definition from "between a male and female" to "between two persons". While the bill intended to acknowledge same-sex couples as "civil partners", it essentially offered them the equivalent legal rights enjoyed by heterosexual married couples. Additionally, three other bills were considered, all of which established a distinct partnership category specifically for civil partners.
In September 2022, the National Human Rights Commission issued a *statement* (2022) exhorting the House of Representatives to legalise same-sex marriage, stating that the law is in accordance with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and that its essence is to "promote and protect the right and freedom to choose a spouse and create a family for people of all genders". 
On 28 September 2023, a new draft *Marriage Equality Bill* (2023), was presented to Parliament. The bill aims to amend Section 1448 of the Civil and Commercial Code by making the marriage law applicable to "any couple, regardless of gender". The First Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives stated that he would take the draft law for review and open it for signatures as soon as possible. On 21 December 2023, the Lower House of Parliament gave preliminary approval to four separate bills, including the Marriage Equality Bill (2023). According to Thailand's legislative process, once a bill obtains the approval of this House during the first reading, a Committee of 39 members is formed to scrutinise the bill before tabling it for the second and third readings and, after that, it would need final approval from the Senate and a royal endorsement. By March 2024, the Marriage Equality Bill had passed the Committee and, on 2 April 2024, it was reported that the Senate had voted in favour of it on a first lecture. 
Finally, in June 2024 the Senate approved the Marriage Equality Bill, which was signed into law by the King in September of the same year and would start to take effect in January 2025.
civil_explan:
In November 2021 the Constitutional Court ruled that Section 1448 of the *Civil and Commercial Code* (1925), which defines marriage as being "between and man and a woman", was not unconstitutional, after a same-sex couple sought and failed to register their union the previous year. The Court, however, instructed the government to implement legislation to protect people from discrimination on the basis of their gender identity.
In June 2022, the Thailand Parliament approved four bills relating to same-sex marriage and civil partnerships. The Civil Partnership Bills submitted by the government and the opposition both extend the definition of life partnerships and civil unions under the current Civil and Commercial Code to include same-sex couples, or “two Thai persons” or “at least one Thai”. This bill will also legally recognise civil unions for foreign same-sex couples, allowing for long stay visas.

marriage_explan: In August 2025, the Legislative Assembly passed the Civil Registration and Digital ID Bill (*Bill No. 7/2025*) (2025), which provisions explicitly prohibiting same-sex marriage.

sources.original_official_filename: TR - LEG - Bill 2-4779 - OR-OFF(tr).pdf

marriage_explan:
In October 2022, at the request of President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, a constitutional reform proposal was submitted to the Assembly to amend Article 41 of the Constitution. According to the President, the word "spouses" in Article 41 is ambiguous and needs to be replaced. Instead, the reform would define the Turkish family as solely consisting of "men, women and children". This is reportedly aimed at "preventing LGBTI+ movements and the like". In January 2023, the Constitutional Commission of Turkey's Grand National Assembly approved *Bill No. 2/4779* (2022) which amends Article 41 of the Constitution to define marriage as "only between a man and a woman".
Since at least February 2025, Turkish media and civil society have warned against the Government's "judicial package" of legislation, which would severely target the rights of LGBTI persons. In October 2025, local and international organisations (such as SPoD, Kaos-GL, Unikuir, ILGA-Europe, Amnesty International or Human Rights Watch) reported that the latest version of this pack would punish anyone who holds an "engagement or wedding ceremony" with a person of their same-sex to imprisonment from one year and six months to four years. In a jurisdiction where same-sex marriage is illegal, this mainly refers to symbolic ceremonies. However, it is unclear whether it would also apply to marriages legally performed abroad or, potentially, even to any private gathering celebrating a same-sex couple.
