sources.original_official_filename: UA - JUD - ECHR CASE OF MAYMULAKHIN AND MARKIV v UKRAINE (2023) - OR-OFF (en).pdf
UA - LEG - Bill 9103 registered partnerships (2023) - OR-OFF (ua).pdf
UA - JUD - District Court Case No 754 12856 (2025) - OR-OFF (uk).pdf
UA - JUD - ECHR CASE OF MAYMULAKHIN AND MARKIV v UKRAINE (2023) - OR-OFF (en).pdf

marriage_explan:
In 2022, in the context of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, a petition to legalise equal marriage obtained the 25,000 signatures that the Ukrainian constitution requires before the president is obliged to respond to it. The petition was based on the need to guarantee the rights of same-sex couples, particularly in the case of the death of one of the partners. President Zelensky replied that the Ukrainian Constitution does not allow for equal marriage, and would therefore need to be amended, something prohibited during wartime. However, he announced that his government would consider the possibility of legally recognising same-sex couples (see section on "civil unions"). 
In June 2023, the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) ruled in *Maymulakhin and Markiv v. Ukraine* (2023) that denying same-sex couples the possibility of having their relationship recognised through a civil union amounted to discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation, and thus condemned Ukraine. However, in keeping with its current case law, the Court also stated that Ukraine is free to restrict access to marriage to different-sex couples.
In July 2025, it was reported that the Desnianskyi District Court had rule in its *Judgment on case No. 754/12856/24* (2025) that a same-sex couple legally married abroad and had a stable cohabitation were to be recognised as a family under Ukrainian law. The Court reached this conclusion relying on the Maymulakhin and Markiv v. Ukraine judgment of the ECHR.
civil_explan:
In 2022, in the context of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, a petition to legalise same-sex marriage obtained the 25,000 signatures that the Ukrainian constitution requires before the president is obliged to respond to it. The petition was based on the need to guarantee the rights of same-sex couples, particularly in the case of the death of one of the partners. President Zelensky replied that the Ukrainian Constitution does not allow for same-sex marriage, and would therefore need to be amended, something prohibited during wartime. However, he announced that his government would consider the possibility of legally recognising same-sex couples. 
On 7 March 2023, a Bill on Registered Civil Partnerships (*Draft Law No. 9103*) (2023) was submitted to the Verkhovna Rada (the Ukrainian Parliament). If passed, the bill would recognise the "voluntary family union of two persons of legal age, of the same or different sex [...] based on mutual respect, mutual understanding, mutual support, mutual rights and obligations". LGBTQ+ military personnel have underscored the importance of this law especially during times of war.
In June 2023, the European Court of Human Rights ruled in *Maymulakhin and Markiv v. Ukraine* (2023) that denying same-sex couples the possibility of having their relationship recognised through a civil union amounted to discrimination on the grounds of sexual orientation.

GB - LEG - Civil Partnership Act (2004) - OR-OFF (en).pdf

marriage_explan:
Same-sex marriage is legal in all constituent countries of the United Kingdom (England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland). Same-sex marriage has been legislated separately by each jurisdiction. 
In 2019, the House of Commons' Foreign Affairs Committee called for all British Overseas Territories to legalise same-sex marriages. 
In March 2023, a Labour MP introduced a *bill* that would make it legal for Church of England clergy to conduct same-sex marriages in church.
civil_explan: The *Civil Partnership Act* (2004) granted same-sex couples access to legal recognition of their relationships. These unions were originally offered only to same-sex couples but then extended to different-sex couples in December 2019. The first partnerships under this law were formalised in December 2005.

sources.original_official_filename: US - JUD (SUP) - Obergefell v Hodges (2014) - OR-OFF (en).pdf
US - JUD (SUP) - Obergefell v Hodges (2014) - OR-OFF (en).pdf
US - LEG - Respect for Marriage Act HR8404 (2022) - OR-OFF (en).pdf

marriage_explan:
The Supreme Court of the United States ruled that same-sex couples had a constitutional right to marry in *Obergefell v. Hodges* (2015), making same-sex marriage available in all 50 states. Prior to this decision, only 13 of the 50 states still outlawed same-sex marriage. 
In February 2019, the Social Security Administration validated the marriage of a gay couple from Minnesota who was able to obtain a marriage licence in 1971 thanks to a clerk's mistake. They are thought to be the longest-married same-sex couple in the United States, and perhaps in the world. 
In July 2022, the House passed the *Respect for Marriage Act* (2022) aiming at codifying the right to same-sex marriage. The bill passed the Senate vote in November 2022. In December 2022, the law was signed into law by the President.
ILGA World is currently finalising the mapping of laws and decisions for all subnational jurisdictions under this category. Please come back shortly.
​In early 2025, legislators in several U.S. states introduced measures challenging the 2015 Obergefell v. Hodges Supreme Court decision that legalized same-sex marriage nationwide. Notably, North Dakota's House passed a resolution urging the Supreme Court to overturn Obergefell, with similar resolutions introduced in Idaho, Michigan, Montana, and South Dakota. Additionally, states like Missouri, Oklahoma, Tennessee, and Texas proposed legislation promoting "covenant marriage," a form of union exclusively for heterosexual couples that imposes stricter divorce requirements.
civil_explan:
Even though there is no federal law providing for civil unions, they are recognised in several states, though five states (Connecticut, Delaware, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, and Vermont) which previously recognised civil unions converted all such unions into marriages after the federal ruling in *Obergefell v. Hodges* (2015).
ILGA World is currently finalising the mapping of laws and decisions for all subnational jurisdictions under this category. Please come back shortly.

US-CA - LEG - ACA 5 (2023) - OR(en).pdf

marriage_explan:
While the California Supreme Court initially ruled a ban on same-sex marriage to be unconstitutional in 2008, the state passed the "Proposition 8" ballot the same year to counter the court's ruling. 
It was not until the conclusion of *Perry v. Schwarzenegger* (2009) and the subsequent appeals by the California government in the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, that marriage equality was fully recognised within the jurisdiction. 
*SB 1306* (2014), which offered a gender-neutral definition of marriage, was signed into law by the Governor of Califonia on 1 January 2015, a few months before the Supreme Court of the United States ruled that same-sex couples had a constitutional right to marry in *Obergefell v. Hodges* (2015), making same-sex marriage available in all 50 states.
In February 2023, a Californian legislator submitted *ACA 5* (2023), which is a constitutional amendment intended to protect same-sex marriage. The amendment would remove discriminatory language in the constitution that recognises "marriage between a man and a woman" only. In June 2023, the California Assembly voted to pass the amendment, followed by the Senate in July. This and other constitutional amendments will be placed on the ballot for voters to decide, either at the next state election in March 2024, or a special election in November 2024.
civil_explan: California has allowed domestic partnerships since 1999 under Section 297 of the *Family Code*. Initially limited in scope, gradual amendments over the years have made such partnerships essentially equivalent to marriage. Section 297.5 (a) states that “domestic partners shall have the same rights, protections, and benefits, and shall be subject to the same responsibilities, obligations, and duties under law […] as are granted to and imposed upon spouses.”

sources.original_official_filename: US - LEG - Montana SB 458 (2023) - OR-OFF(en).pdf

marriage_explan:
Same-sex marriage was legalised in 2014 by the US District Court for the District of Montana ruling in the case of *Rolando v. Fox* (2014).
In May 2023, *Senate Bill 458* (2023) amended Section 40-1-107 of the Montana Code Annotated (MCA) so that the term "sex" (included in marriage certificates) follows the amended definition now incorporated into Section 1-1-201 of the MCA. This provision defines "sex" based on reproductive criteria in the following terms: "Female" means "a member of the human species who, under normal development, has XX chromosomes and produces or would produce relatively large, relatively immobile gametes, or eggs, during her life cycle and has a reproductive and endocrine system oriented around the production of those gametes. An individual who would otherwise fall within this definition, but for a biological or genetic condition, is female"; "Male" means "a member of the human species who, under normal development, has XY chromosomes and produces or would produce small, mobile gametes, or sperm, during his life cycle and has a reproductive and endocrine system oriented around the production of those gametes. An individual who would otherwise fall within this definition, but for a biological or genetic condition, is male".

marriage_explan: Same-sex marriage became legal after the Supreme Court of New Jersey ruled in favour of a local advocacy group which had litigated the matter on behalf of several same-sex couples in *Garden State Equality v. Dow* (2013). In 2022 the law *A5367* (2022) which enshrines same-sex marriage, was signed into law. It was seen as intending to guarantee the right to marry for same-sex couples in the face of the conservative majority in the Supreme Court.
civil_explan:
The *Domestic Partnership Act* (2003) gave same-sex couples registered as domestic partners limited rights to tax exemptions and to make medical decisions on behalf of one another. 
Following the New Jersey Supreme Court *Lewis v. Harris* (2005) ruling, which found the “unequal dispensation of rights” to same-sex couples to be in contravention of the state’s constitution, the local legislature revised marriage laws and adopted the *Civil Union Act* (2006), which came into force the following year. Under this act, same-sex couples could enter into civil unions and enjoy the same rights and responsibilities as married couples.

US-VA - LEG - Senate Joint Resolution No. 242 (2023) - OR-OFF(en).pdf
US-VA - LEG - S.B. 1096 (2023) - OR-OFF(en).pdf

marriage_explan:
The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit ruled in *Bostic v. Schaefer* (2014) against the state's prohibition on marriage equality, but it was not until 2020 that *House Bill 1490* (2020) would pass and repeal discriminatory sections of the existing marriage legislation.
The pre-filed *House Joint Resolution No. 460* (2023) was set to be discussed in the 2023 state legislative session. This resolution would seek to repeal the constitutional ban on same-sex marriages in Section 15A of the Constitution of Virginia, which defines marriage as that between a man and a woman. This resolution was reported to have been left and died at the committee level in February 2023. Another *resolution* by the Senate was also introduced and has since passed the senate vote as of February 2023. However, this resolution also subsequently died at the committee level later in February 2023.
In January 2023, the state Senate committee approved *S.B. 1096* (2023) which amends the Code of Virginia, adding section 20-13.2 stating that “a marriage between two parties shall be lawful regardless of the sex or gender of such persons”. As of February 2023, the bill has reportedly failed to pass at the House level.

US - LEG - Washington civil union requirements CHAPTER 26 Civil Code (2007) - OR (en).pdf

sources.original_official_filename: US - LEG - Washington Referendum Measure 74 (2012) - OR-OFF (en).pdf

marriage_explan: While the Governor initially signed into law the *Revised Code of Washington Title 26 Chapter 04 Section 010* (2012) to offer a gender-neutral definition of marriage, marriage equality only came into force after the public upheld the legislation in a 54% to 46% vote, under *Referendum Measure No. 74* (2012).
civil_explan: The State of Washington adopted civil unions for same-sex couples, called State Registered Domestic Partnerships, under *Chapter 26* of the state’s legal code in 2007.

sources.original_filename: US - JUD - West Virginia McGee v Cole (2014) - OR (en).pdf

marriage_explan: The United States District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia overturned the statutory ban on same-sex marriage in *McGee v. Cole* (2014).

sources.original_filename: US - JUD - Wisconsin Wolf v Walker (2014) - OR (en).pdf

sources.original_official_filename: US-WI - LEG - Chapter 770 (2009) - OR(en).pdf

marriage_explan: Marriage equality was legalised in Wisconsin after four couples challenged the law banning same-sex marriage. The United States District Court for the Western District of Wisconsin ruled in their favour in *Wolf v. Walker* (2014), with the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals later affirming that decision.
civil_explan: The Wisconsin Legislature enacted regulations on domestic partnerships under *Chapter 770* (2009) of its Civil Code, giving same-sex couples registered limited rights to property inheritance, as well as hospital and jail visitation rights. Joint adoptions are not permitted under such a union.

sources.original_filename: US - JUD - Wyoming Guzzo v Mead (2015) - OR (en).pdf

marriage_explan: In 2014, the United States District Court for the District of Wyoming ruled in *Guzzo v. Mead* (2014) in favour of several couples that sought the recognition of their same-sex marriages celebrated in another state.The Court also declared that the ban on same-sex marriages was a violation of the rights of same-sex couples.

sources.original_official_filename: UR - LEG - Law on Marriage Equality (2013) - OR-OFF (es).pdf

sources.original_filename: UY - LEG - Union Concubinaria Civil Union Law (2008) - OFF (es).pdf

marriage_explan: The *Law on Marriage Equality* (2013) redefined marriage as the union of two persons “of different or same-sex”.
civil_explan: *Law No. 18,246* (2008) affords same-sex couples the right to have their union recognised (locally referred to as “unión concubinaria”).

sources.original_official_filename: VU - Bill to Amend the Marriage Act (2024) - OR-OFF (en).pdf

marriage_explan: On 14 November 2024, Parliament passed the *Bill to Amend the Marriage Act* (2024), officially banning same-sex marriage by explicitly defining marriage as a union between "a male and a female."

sources.original_official_filename: VN - LEG - Law on Marriage and the Family (2014) - OR-OFF (vi).pdf

marriage_explan: According to ILGA Asia's 2021 "Dare To Dream" report, in 2013 the *Law on Marriage and Family* (2014) was revised to remove the prohibition on same-sex wedding ceremonies and cohabitation of same-sex couples. However, while same-sex marriages are not prohibited under the new law, Article 8(2) maintains that such unions are not recognised by the State.

sources.original_official_filename: FR - LEG - LAW 2013-404 Opening marriage to same-sex couples (2013) - OR-OFF (fr).pdf
FR - LEG - Civil Solidarity Pact Law (PACS), Law 99-944 (1999) - OR-OFF (fr).pdf
FR - LEG - Civil Code Article 143 amendment on same sex marriage (2013) - OR-OFF (fr).pdf

marriage_explan: In France, the Law Opening Marriage to Same-Sex Couples (*Law No. 2013-404*) (2013) amended the *Civil Code* to legalise same-sex marriages. This law applies to Wallis and Futuna.
civil_explan: Article 70 of Law 2009-549 (2009) amended Article 14 of *Law No. 99-944* (1999) to make the French Civil Solidarity Pact applicable to Wallis and Futuna. Law No. 99-944 (1999) confers some legal recognition to same-sex couples outside of marriage.
